TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Leader of the Government in the Senate explain the rationale behind the Cabinet instruction to departments to cut drastically expenditure for the remainder of the financial year? Is it true that, as a result of this decision, instructions have been sent to the staff of honourable members and honourable senators that they can no longer claim travel or overtime payment? Is it true that the Minister for Administrative Services has admitted that he did not know of this instruction and has said that it will be revoked? Is it also a fact that an instruction went to the Australian Federal Police that overtime payments must be reduced by $2.5m? Can we expect that the Minister will also revoke that directive? What instructions concerning expenditure cut backs have been given to the Government Information Unit? Has it received telexed instructions to cut back travel, overtime, use of motor vehicles, office requisites, computer services or anything else?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The rationale behind the Government's intention to reduce expenditure as far as possible is, of course, to reduce the deficit, thereby taking the pressure off loan borrowing in the community and thus to take pressure off interest rates. I would think that this would have the support of all Australians. I understand that a misunderstanding took place about a memorandum and a wrong conclusion was drawn. I understand that the particular cuts to which Senator Button has referred were not intended in any of the areas mentioned. I am not aware of what has happened regarding the Government Information Unit. It is one of the most economic units in terms of cost of any government in Australia. It is many times smaller than that which is led by the Government headed by the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party, Mr Wran, and it is much smaller than that which the previous Whitlam Government operated. So there has been a continuous economy in that regard.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ELECTRICITY SUPPLY TO THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for National Development and Energy aware that the Australian Capital Territory has an annual entitlement of electricity from the Snowy Mountains Scheme but that almost 60 per cent of our electricity is purchased from New South Wales? In view of this, can the Minister confirm that up to 20 per cent of the present New South Wales daily consumption of electricity is being provided by Victoria and the Snowy Mountains Scheme? Can Victoria and the Snowy Mountains Scheme continue to prop up New South Wales in winter and avoid major blackouts? Can the Minister confirm that although the Liddell generator plant supplies 10 per cent of New South Wales capacity, it will not be in use again before June or July of this year and that because of continuing industrial disputes in that State it may be considerably later? Will the Minister comment on whether there is any risk to the Australian Capital Territory of blackouts this winter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can fully understand Senator Reid's concern that with heavy reliance upon New South Wales power generation Australian Capital Territory residents could be at risk in the winter months. As to the supply of electricity, the daily consumption for New South Wales is at present in the order of 100 gigawatt hours, of which Victoria is supplying around 10 per cent and the Snowy Mountains Scheme between 5 per cent and 15 per cent. In effect, up to 20 per cent of New South Wales power has been coming from the Snowy and Victoria. It is true that the Premier of New South Wales has indicated that he will largely forgo the maintenance that normally takes place in power stations in summer time. It is very valid to maintain them in summer time because they are used heavily in winter time. The Premier has indicated that he will forgo it so as not to draw down further on water in summer time. Already the draw-down on water on the Snowy is such that there will be a discounted amount for winter time as that is the ordinary agreement. So there is, in fact, some risk. The Australian Capital Territory has an entitlement of 670 gigawatt hours per year from the Snowy. Last year's total consumption was 1,558 gigawatt hours. Therefore, 57 per cent was provided by New South Wales under contract. The sad fact of the matter is that the installed capacity of electric power in New South Wales well exceeds what the normal demand should be. Indeed, over the last five years or more, the installed capacity has been some 30 per cent in excess of demand. So the problem is not installed capacity; it lies at the heart of maintenance and operational practices, and therefore it lies at the heart of mismanagement.

ANSWER.PARA: Incidentally, when Mr Wran was asked what was the cause, he said that he really did not know. The Premier is on record as saying that. Liddell, in fact, has four 500 megawatt units.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. I again draw your attention to the fact that the Minister in replying to a question from a Government senator is taking the opportunity to make a long speech to support the broken down candidate for the Liberal Party in the Lowe by-election. I draw your attention to your previous rulings and ask you to draw the Minister's attention to them.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—The question was asked by a senator for the Australian Capital Territory. What does the Australian Capital Territory have to do with Liddell?

—I was asked about the capacity of Liddell power station. It has a total installed capacity of 2,000 megawatts, that is, four units of 500 megawatts. Three of the four units have been broken down. To put it in perspective, Liddell represents almost one-quarter of the total installed capacity of New South Wales of some 8,300 megawatts, from memory, excluding the amount supplied by the Snowy. As I understand it, set No. 2 at Liddell will be back in March, set No. 3 will be back in June and set No. 4 will be back in July . Each are of 500 megawatts. If indeed that is achieved the people of that State and of the Australian Capital Territory will be in some peril with regard to their electric power for winter. Those who claim good management in terms of Labor's policies have a lot to answer for in that they cannot supply the necessary power to the people of New South Wales.
—Mr President, I ask that the document quoted from by the Minister be tabled.

—I am perfectly happy to table it. Perhaps it might be of more interest if it were incorporated. It is a single sheet. It would therefore be available for all. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
—I ask that the document be tabled so that we can peruse it now. I am most happy for it to be incorporated as well.
—I table the document.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted for the document to be incorporated in Hansard?

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Minister-
Australian Capital Territory-ACT has an entitlement of 670 Gwh per year from Snowy. Last year's total consumption 1558 Gwh. Therefore 57% was provided by N.S .W. last year under contract.
New South Wales-Daily NSW consumption at present is about 100 Gigawatt hours of which Victoria is supplying around 10% and the Snowy between 5 and 15% ( depending on various factors).

Present public NSW posture is that set 2 at Liddell will be back up in March; set 3 at Liddell will be back up in June; set 4 at Liddell will be back up in July (each 500 MW). (Vales Point are 660 MW).

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented by an interjection of Senator McLaren in which he claimed that I as an Australian Capital Territory Senator had no interest in the functioning of the Liddell power station. The Australian Capital Territory purchases 60 per cent of its electricity from New South Wales, under an agreement, and it is of great concern to this community that New South Wales should manage its electricity efficiently and maintain the supply.

—Mr President, you have frequently ruled it out of order to make claims about misrepresentation during Question Time. Surely the good Senator can wait till the end of Question Time as she usually does.

—Can the Minister for Social Security give the Senate some indication of the Government's intentions concerning legislation to prevent the avoidance of income tests using interest free deposits and to limit the amount of money held in cheque accounts when calculating income for the income test, as he foreshadowed in the last Budget and as he later foreshadowed for early in this session, so that the many pensioners in this country who are in a state of uncertainty can have that uncertainty relieved?

—I agree with the suggestion in Senator Grimes's question that it is a matter on which it is desirable to have some certainty for the reason he has indicated. Unfortunately, although I have done a considerable amount of work on that legislation, I do not have it in a state in which I can bring it to the chamber yet. I can only assure him that I will do so as soon as possible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney- General to my question without notice of 25 February 1981 relating to compensation programs for victims of crime within Australia, specifically in respect of Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory jurisdiction. In answer to my question on this matter the Attorney- General stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The matter has been referred to the Legislative Drafting Division of my Department for the preparation of an ordinance for the ACT. I am advised that the ordinance has reached an advanced stage of preparation, and I am hoping that the legislation will be brought into force later this year.

With regard to the Attorney-General's response I ask: What further consideration has he given to the matter of an ordinance for the Australian Capital Territory on this subject? When will the necessary legislation be brought into force?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no information as to the situation with respect to this ordinance at present. I will have to make some further inquiries in relation to it and advise the honourable senator as soon as possible.

—I direct a question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate . I refer to last week's announcement by the Reagan Administration that it will provide a further $55m in emergency military aid-I emphasise that it is for military aid-to the ruling junta in El Salvador. Is the Minister aware that this decision to boost military aid follows widespread reports of a sickening massacre by Salvadorean troops last December in Morozan Province where reliable sources have estimated that up to 1,000 people were systematically slaughtered by the military and that even United States spokesmen concede that many civilians were killed? Is this consistent with the philosophy of some United States hawks that 'the head of the junta is a rotten son-of-a-bitch but at least he is our son-of-a-bitch'? In the light of this information, which is merely the latest well-documented report of atrocities committed by the military government against civilians, will the Minister bring pressure to bear on the United States to reverse its decision to send more military aid to El Salvador and to allow the people of that country to resolve their own problems in as peaceful a fashion as possible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the latter part of Senator Chipp's question, I understand that the Government of El Salvador has announced its intention to hold elections for a constituent--
—With bayonets.
—I suggest that honourable senators on the Labor side should read the speech made by former Senator John Wheeldon on this matter when he was a member of the Senate. It may be illuminating to them.
—A very former senator.
—I am sorry that they are denigrating him now. Senator Wheeldon was a distinguished senator.
—I denigrated him at the time.

—It is to be noted that the Labor senator interjected that he denigrated him at the time. I am sorry that that should be so. I think Senator Wheeldon deserved a better fate. He was a person with very considerable knowledge of foreign affairs and, happily, an independent mind. I now direct myself to the question. As to the latter part, the Government of El Salvador has announced its intention to hold elections for a constituent assembly on 28 March . The Australian Government hopes the elections will contribute in due course to a process of peaceful political settlement and reconciliation in El Salvador. The declared intention of the armed left wing guerrilla groups to disrupt the elections is to be deplored. That must be kept in mind. Although El Salvador is far removed from Australia the loss of life and the extent of human suffering there, which Senator Chipp has spoken about, continue to be of very deep concern to the Australian Government. The Government of the United States of America has taken its stand on El Salvador in the face of evidence of external support for left wing guerrilla movements operating inside the country. The Australian Government fully understands why the United States should view these developments so close to home with such deep misgivings. The United States has a long-standing interest and role in Central America, a region of direct strategic concern for it.
—You can say that again.

—One can always see the hatred for the United States coming through in the interjections. The anti-American philosophy of a left wing socialist party comes through very strongly indeed. The fact is that the misgivings in the United States have been heightened by the continued external support for left wing guerrilla groups that have caused the Government of El Salvador to request further military aid. At the same time the Australian Government has noted also that the United States Government has underlined the importance of economic and social reform in El Salvador and has given over $126m in non-military economic aid during the last year. That ought to be taken into consideration. I do not say this in response to Senator Chipp, because his question was a serious one, but I say that it is a great pity that the Australian Labor Party tends always to side with left wing radicals instead of looking at the picture in the wider scene. Having said that, the Government deplores the brutality and the slaughter in El Salvador--
—So does the Catholic Church in El Salvador.

—I think the honourable senator should say that a little louder. It might be helpful. The Government of course deplores the killing of people in El Salvador and looks forward with the hope that the forthcoming election may well go a long way towards resolving the matter.

—I ask a supplementary question. I thank Senator Sir John Carrick for a full and informative answer. The supplementary question concerns what seemed to be the main thrust of his answer, namely, that there are to be elections on 28 March, and that this was a step forward. I simply ask the honourable senator, without trying to score points: Seeing that the Government places a lot of credence on that event, is the Government satisfied that those elections will be supervised by the military? Is this Government satisfied that the elections can be conducted in a free and democratic atmosphere?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I stated that the election would be held on 28 March as a matter of fact and as a matter of hope in both cases. I indicated also that there was evidence that left wing guerrilla forces were seeking to disrupt the holding of the election and that, therefore, there may well be obstacles in the situation. I am not able to say from the knowledge that I have immediately how my Government may regard the ability of the El Salvadorean Government to hold those elections but I will seek further information on the point that has been queried.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing both the Minister for Health and the Minister for Administrative Services. An article in a newspaper today suggested that the Government may soon be offering to the people of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands some form of self-determination. As honourable senators would know, the Government has recently completed the construction of an animal quarantine station on the Cocos (Keeling) Islands which is of considerable importance to Australia. If the article is correct, can the Minister give an assurance that Australia's control over the station is secured for the future?

—Like other senators, I am aware of the importance which the new animal quarantine facility will have for Australia and for a whole range of activities in relation to our own quarantine precautions. I am aware also that Mr Wilson, the Minister whom I represent, recently had discussions with the Cocos community in which the matter of self-determination was raised. The Minister has indicated to the islanders that they should choose the time at which this self-determination or independence should take place. They have yet to make a decision as to when that time should be. The choices that are available to the islanders seem to be integration with Australia-if that happened there would be no problem in the matter which Senator Thomas has raised -they may decide to enter into a state of free association with Australia, or they may decide to become completely independent. It is up to the islanders to decide what they wish and to set some time. The Australian Government has told the United Nations that it will arrange for the act of determination to take place when requested. I am quite certain that whatever outcome flows from that act of determination, it will be the desire of the Australian Government to ensure that the animal quarantine facility continues to be available. Whichever of those options is chosen I am sure that appropriate arrangements will be made with the Cocos islanders to ensure that we still have access to those facilities .

—My question, which is directed to the Attorney-General, refers to the massive dimensions of what I might call embezzlement that can occur in the manipulation of or rorts in computer operations. I ask the Minister : Firstly, is he satisfied that our federal legislation is adequate to grapple with such white collar crime manifestations and, secondly, is he satisfied that our law enforcement agencies have sufficient sophistication in this industry to detect the offenders?

—As we know, the question of crime generally is largely a matter for State laws. Crime by computer has certain technical and sophisticated problems associated with it, but essentially it is still a matter for the application of the criminal laws as they exist at present. The Commonwealth's responsibility is limited to the Australian Capital Territory and matters involving computers that perhaps should be operated by the Commonwealth, or the use of computers to defraud the Commonwealth. There have not been many cases involving breaches of the criminal law by the use of computers operated by the Commonwealth, although I understand that there have been some convictions. So it is certainly not beyond the capacity of the criminal law or the potential of the present criminal investigators to cope with this problem. So far as I am aware, at the moment there are no deficiencies in the Crimes Act which would require a special amendment to cope with this problem. The Senate will recall that during the last session of the Parliament I proposed a number of amendments to the Crimes Act, so we do keep a very close eye on it. If any such deficiencies are pointed up, of course we would seek to take steps to provide for them. As far as criminal investigation and law enforcement are concerned, those are matters for the Australian Federal Police, who I understand have some special training in regard to the possibility of computer crime. I will refer to the Minister for Administrative Services for a more detailed answer to that part of the honourable senator's question relating to what is happening with the police.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In a recent Press release the Treasurer, Mr Howard, announced the extension of sales tax refund provisions as they apply to books, schools, universities, government departments, local authorities, any other public authority that is entitled to sales tax exemption and any other organisation which is granted exemption by Division XI of the First Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemption and Classifications) Act. He indicated that the application for a refund must be made direct to the Commissioner of Taxation. Is the Treasurer aware of the imposition that will be placed on schools in remote areas that have no clerical assistance and only one teacher? To assist these schools will he consider the total abolition of sales tax on all class 4 and 5 schools?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — Judging from the nature of the question, I think there is some misinformation in the mind of the honourable senator or in the mind of whoever asked her to gain a response on this matter because certain tax exempt organisations have long been permitted to claim from the Commissioner of Taxation the sales tax component of goods bought at retail price, thus including sales tax in that retail price. On 18 December last year the Treasurer announced an extension of this option to schools, universities, councils and other tax exempt organisations which were not previously included in that exemption. It is to be stressed that this is an option and there is no compulsion on any tax exempt organisation to reclaim sales tax direct from the Commissioner of Taxation. The Treasurer advises that organisations are at complete liberty to adopt or to retain the alternative arrangement under which books or other articles are bought at wholesale price or indented through a retailer from wholesale tax free stocks and invoiced free of sales tax on production of a sales tax exemption certificate.

ANSWER.PARA: Since all schools and other institutes of learning are exempt from sales tax there is no question of the total abolition of sales tax on class 4 and 5 schools. They are already exempt from sales tax. I think that answer responds to the main part of Senator Bjelke-Petersen's question. The class 4 and 5 schools are already exempt.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. On 21 October, during the adjournment debate, and on 17 November 1981, during Question Time, I sought support from the Government to protest about certain arrests in Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia. I have now received written replies from the Minister for Foreign Affairs in relation to both matters indicating that whilst the Government shares my concern about the cases it does not intend to lodge a protest because of the likelihood of a negative result. Is it an inflexible rule of the Government never to protest about apparent human rights violations in overseas countries? Are any exceptions ever made? Does it depend on the severity of the case or the volume of noise from people in Australia or, indeed, on the colour of the eyes of the individual senator making the request? If not, why the different approach taken by the Government on such cases?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not aware of the response received by Senator Harradine to the matters raised by him. I will raise that with the Minister for Foreign Affairs. As far as the inflexibility of the rule is concerned, determinations need to be made on certain issues and I think it would be right to say that there is no inflexible rule. Certainly it does not depend on some of the matters raised by Senator Harradine. In the cases to which Senator Harradine referred, the Minister has given his decision and stated the Government's attitude with regard to it. I will seek any further information which may be available and will refer again to the Minister the question Senator Harradine has raised on these matters.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator LEWIS

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment to a statement by the new Chairman of the National Australia Day Committee, Mr John Newcombe, that Australians are facing an identity crisis over what they and their country stand for and that the National Australia Day Committee has decided to hold a seminar later this year in an attempt to learn the views of the public. I also refer to the editorial comment of the Brisbane Courier-Mail in regard to this proposal which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: In the Middle Ages learned academics gathered for the Medieval equivalent of weekend seminars to discuss how many angels could dance on the head of a pin.

Can the Minister say whether this Committee had any evidence and, if so, what evidence that Australians are facing an identity crisis? The Minister might agree with me that Australians are well aware of their national identity and proud of it and are proud of this nation and its history which has produced that national identity. Further, in the light of the Prime Minister's statement that the purpose of this Committee is to advise on and to co-ordinate efforts to foster the observance of Australia Day through existing organisations, can the Minister tell the Senate whether this proposed folly is within the charter of the Committee? Finally, can the Minister tell the Senate how much this nonsense is going to cost the taxpayers of Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is probably unwise for people who serve in the Senate, honourable senators, to talk to the Australian public about identity crises of any kind. People say that we have our own identity problems here. I take it from what the honourable senator says that he is not in favour of the proposed seminar, if I understand the question. I will pass on to the Minister the question that he has asked. I believe I am correct though in saying that Senator Neville Bonner is a member of the National Australia Day Committee, and while sitting here in the Senate he will have taken at first hand the points that Senator Lewis has made. I will come back to Senator Lewis with a detailed answer as soon as one is available.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. In the absence of any satisfactory steps by the Queensland Government to provide for Aboriginal and Islander ownership of Aboriginal reserves in Queensland, and bearing in mind the frequent commitments by the Minister in this place last year to the effect that he would support the securing of Aboriginal title to those reserves, is the Minister now prepared to support Commonwealth legislation to establish Aboriginal and Islander ownership of Queensland reserves?

—I made clear last year what the Commonwealth position was. I made clear then the four principles which needed to be satisfied in any solution in Queensland, and I indicated that negotiations were proceeding between the Queensland Government and Aboriginal communities and between the Commonwealth and Queensland governments. Those negotiations are continuing. I am confident that they are going to reach a satisfactory conclusion. I do not believe it appropriate for us to talk of Commonwealth intervention at this stage . I do not believe that will add anything.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Can I ask the Minister how long the Aboriginal people living in Queensland have to wait for these apparently unending negotiations before he will be prepared to take any action at a Commonwealth level?

—The honourable senator can ask. Let me just say to her that it is in the interests of everyone, including Aboriginal people in Queensland, that we reach a negotiated solution. It is not in the interests of Aboriginal people that we proceed unnecessarily upon any kind of confrontation.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport to a recent announcement that Qantas Airways Ltd and Garuda Indonesian Airways will shortly commence a Port Hedland to Bali weekly direct service using exclusively Garuda F28 aircraft and that the regular single economy class fare will be $399 or 29.6c per kilometre. I ask the Minister: Inasmuch as the regular single economy class fare from Port Hedland to Perth, a distance of 1,311 kilometres-almost the identical distance from Port Hedland to Bali-is $170.80 or 13.02c per kilometre, has the Government approved or does it intend to approve a Port Hedland to Bali fare which is considerably more than double the cost of flights over similar distances within Western Australia? I further ask: Is the Minister aware that the Qantas Perth to Bali standard economy one-way fare is rated at 18.2c per kilometre, approximately 40 per cent cheaper than the Qantas Bali to Port Hedland fare rate?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator MESSNER

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the actual proposal which has been put foward has not yet been formally approved by the Department. I understand that was the main point which Senator Crichton-Browne was seeking a reply to immediately. However, he would know that it is the Government's intention, following reviews of policy in recent times, especially the Review of Commonwealth Functions decisions in 1981, that Qantas should be granted greater flexibility in setting fares to meet market conditions where Australia's arrangements permit that. I understand that Qantas has proposed not only normal economy fares on this route but also a range of lower promotional fares which are comparable with those available to or from points in Australia other than Port Hedland. A promotional fare applicable to round trip travel between Port Hedland and Bali includes a 28 -day excursion fare priced from $420 or 15.6c per kilometre, an individual inclusive tour fare with an air fare component priced from $296 or 11c per kilometre and a group inclusive tour fare priced from $240 or 8.9c per kilometre . I think that compares very favourably with the figure of 13.02c given by Senator Crichton-Browne.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator McLaren-Mr President, I ask that the documents referred to by the Minister be tabled.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Does the Minister accept that the only way in which one can draw a valid comparison of air fare cost structuring is by using the standard economy one-way fare? I further ask the Minister: Can he explain why Qantas is chartering Garuda F28 aircraft when Airlines of Western Australia, with Australian crews, has F28 aircraft available? Is he aware of the fact that Airlines of Western Australia is presently doing charter services from Port Hedland to Bali at half the fare presently suggested by Qantas?

—As I pointed out in my opening remarks, the fact is that the proposal has not yet been formally approved in any way by the Government. The points which I was making during the latter part of my answer referred, of course, to Qantas's own determinations in this matter. Consequently we will be looking for further deliberations by the Government on this matter before a final conclusion is reached.

—My question, which is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, follows somewhat the question asked by my leader, Senator Button, earlier today. I refer to the directive from the Department of Finance instructing all departments to withdraw travel warrants, cut overtime and reduce purchases of equipment, goods and services. Has the Government received a report , now reportedly more than a year old, that 444 staff members are employed by 28 Federal departments and 47 statutory authorities, whose duties are primarily directed or related to dissemination of information relating to Government functions? Is it not a fact that the sale of the Government's policies by these officers is regarded as unsatisfactory by the Government? Is the Government similarly critical of the Government Information Unit and its failure to sell the Fraser Government and its policies? In view of this large public relations armoury of the Government, what is the purpose of the new proposed information unit under the organisation of the Department of Administrative Services? How can these expensive exercises remain untouched in view of the restraints suggested when all other Government departments are expected to reduce their expenditures between now and the end of the financial year?

—I am not aware of the report to which Senator Gietzelt has referred. I will ask my colleagues to see whether such a report exists. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Button proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of 'New Federalism'.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of the Fraser Government's new federalism, which was proclaimed some six years ago, is I suppose in some ways important as an academic sort of political discussion in terms of a government's failures, its promises, its hopes, its aspirations and its failure to deliver in respect of those promises. It is important also to millions of people in Australia in terms of the delivery of basic community services by either State or Federal governments. As I said six years ago, new federalism was first trumpeted as the beginning of a new era in Commonwealth- State relations. I just remind the Senate that it was to be a new era of co- operation between the Government and the States. Less than one year ago, I remind the Senate also, the co-operation between the Fraser Government and the States and the level it had reached were well illustrated by the fact that the Treasurer, Mr Howard, and the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, came away from a Premiers Conference like a couple of giggly cadet salesmen in a used car yard boasting about how they had cheated the States of $70m which would have been available to the States if they had adopted a different approach and level of pressure for it at that Premiers Conference.
—It wasn't a question of cheating.

—Senator Teague wants to be semantic about it but that was the boast: 'We outdid the States by $70m'. That was a triumph, I would take it in the honourable senator's terms, of co-operation between Federal and State governments! The new federalism which is illustrated by the noise that was made at the beginning and by the incident last year in terms of its success, was a brain child of the Liberal Party's leading intellectual, according to the National Times, Senator Carrick.
—When did the National Times say that?

—It said it very early in the piece. It might not write that now; it said it some time ago. I refer the Senate to the sort of things which were being said about new federalism in 1976. In April 1976, for example, Senator Carrick said:

SPEECH.PARA: The basic principle of federalism is that the people know best and that it is a good thing to bring government as close to the people as possible, to consult them, to invite them to express their views . . .
I agree that this is an impeccable statement. He went on to say in the same month in 1976:

It is fundamental to federalism that there should be teamwork, a working dialogue, in all three spheres. It is fundamental that the Commonwealth should be inviting the States and local government to co-operate in economic management .
The new federalism was promoted in those sorts of terms. There was lot of rhetoric about an end to centralism, for example, in fiscal policy. Senator Carrick said, again in 1976:
We have said that centralism is a foul thing, that it corrupts government, that it destroys the sovereignty of the States and others and that is bad.

Since that period of high-flown rhetoric when attacks on centralism were regarded as good political mileage a lot of rhetoric has flowed under the bridge . It was quite clear that, according to the Government in 1976, new federalism was going to provide a barrier against centralist authoritarian control. In 1976 , in an official Government statement, it was said:
We must restructure our forms and institutions of government and our attitudes of mind to achieve co-operation not conflict, partnership and not domination.

In the light of that sort of statement the shoddy exercise at last year's Premiers Conference draws a dramatic illustration of how those high-flown attitudes of mind have been debased by this Government. They were high-flown attitudes of mind. I personally have a high regard for many of the principles underlying the notion of new federalism. There is a lot to be said for them in terms of good government. The fact that they have failed is an indictment of bad government.

It is six years later now and we can see what a farce this policy has been. It is an additional failure, a sham and a classic example of this Government's capacity to say one thing and to do another. The history of new federalism has been a record of unfulfilled promises and empty undertakings. After six years of new federalism it is clear that the only change that has taken place is that the Commonwealth's grip over State finances has, in fact, strengthened. Conflict rather than co-operation, domination rather than partnership, continue to characterise Commonwealth-State relations while competition and self-interest are the distinguishing features of interstate relations. That is not just an indictment of the Fraser Government; of course, State governments are involved in that process as well. The States, far from becoming more responsible and accountable in fiscal matters, have had to rely more and more on Commonwealth financial assistance. As Professor Mathews said in his recent paper:

After six years of the new arrangements it has become clear that they have not significantly changed the basis of intergovernmental financial arrangements in Australia, except in the direction of strengthening the Commonwealth's control over State functions.
Consultation with the States on fiscal policy has become a joke. The Commonwealth has continued to make unilateral decisions about the shared revenue base and the structure of Commonwealth taxation.

It is worth recording this ill-fated policy and the stages of it as it has whimpered to an end. The so-called new arrangements were based on 35 points of understanding which were agreed at three Premiers Conferences in 1976. they included promises to keep the States informed of changes to their tax entitlements and to institute a periodical review of the tax-sharing arrangements. A major review was to take place in 1981. What happened to all these laudable but insincere promises? During the first four years the States simply got what they were guaranteed under the old formula, the so-called Whitlam formula. The only guarantee for 1981-82 was that the States' tax grants would be less in absolute terms than in the previous years. Given the rate of inflation this means only that the States would get less money. The so-called review of the tax-sharing arrangements in 1981 simply took the shape of a unilateral declaration by the present government that new and drastic arrangements were to take place in tax-sharing arrangements. There was not even a pretence of consultation, not even a pretence of new federalism co-operation.

Similarly, the so-called razor gang-the Government's completely discredited stunt of a year ago-is another grand example of the failure of the Government to consult with the States as it professed to do. I will, of course, refer to Professor Mathews a lot because he is one of the most reputabe commentators and most informed academics on Federal-State relations. He said about the razor gang :

The main purpose of the Review of Commonwealth Functions seemed to be concerned not with improving efficiency in government but rather with reducing the Commonwealth Budget deficit by shifting expenditure responsibilities to the States or by disposing of Commonwealth property and activities to private enterprise.

It was not concerned, as he said, with efficiency in government. As we have often described it, it is a cosmetic exercise designed to achieve anything but efficiency in government. It is quite clear now that the States have had a raw deal out of the so-called new federalism. Even those premiers who enthusiastically embraced the new arrangements in 1976-some of them being slow thinkers, I suspect-in the mistaken belief that they would be better off have found that they have been victims of a Federal Government trap. On 3 April this year that trap will spring tight round the corpse of Lindsay Thompson in Victoria. He is one of the first victims of the decline in ability to deliver government services because of the consequences of his Government's acquiescence in the new federalism policy. Financially, the States are no better off in real terms. Restraints continue to be imposed upon them by unilateral Commonwealth decree.

Let me give honourable senators some examples about matters upon which the States have been misled. In 1975 the Liberal Party policy speech promised to minimise special purpose payments to States by absorbing them in general purpose grants in order to give the States responsibility for programs. Not a bad idea! But what has happened? The Government has simply cut programs by reducing special purposes grants without allowing tax entitlements to grow to allow States to take over the responsibilities apparently allotted to them. So one has had a significant decline in the delivery of government services because of this action by the Government. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The question of State taxes was, of course, fundamental to the new federalism. Fraser federalism or Carrick federalism promised each State the right to impose an income tax surcharge on its people or to give them a rebate. The Fraser Government has shown a total lack of interest in providing any tax room for the States to impose such taxation. There has been no co-operation or consultation on the question of what tax room would be allowed to the States in order to deal with that stage of proposed new federalism to make the States responsible for gathering revenue in respect of their expenditure.

SPEECH.PARA: The so-called 1981 review was a general review in that year of the tax sharing arrangements. But after that it became hard to find any bits, even of the new federalism, amongst the rubble that was left of the Government's policy on Commonwealth- State relations. If we look hard to see what remained we find that no State henceforth was to receive any less in its tax sharing grant than it received in absolute money terms the previous year. The guarantee does not mean very much. As Professor Mathews put it:

For 1981-82 there was to be a substantial reduction in the amount which the States would have received under the original personal income tax sharing arrangements, to be affected by arbitrarily increasing total State and Northern Territory tax sharing grants by only 9 per cent when the tax sharing formula would have resulted in an increase of 16.6 per cent.

That is to say-again I quote-'by arbitrarily acting in the way in which the Commonwealth Government did'. The States, of course, retain the right to impose income tax, a right which is laughable in the face of a tax burden which is already high and inequitably distributed. The Commonwealth retains the right to declare any change in the Commonwealth's tax to be a special surcharge and so excluded from the tax sharing base-a ludicrous and ironic commitment to consultation, a policy which, despite all its statements and all its rhetoric, the Government has never carried out.

The Fraser brand of federalism and its architects have duped the Australian people again. It is another example of the Government's giving with the one hand and taking away with the other. A further example is the attitude of this Commonwealth Government to the borrowing programs of the States for the purpose of financing infrastructure development.

This whole excursion into the new federalism has been an exercise in deception and an illustration of the failure of this Government to develop a rational Commonwealth-State fiscal policy. The features of the present division of fiscal responsibility are clear. Revenue collection is still overwhelmingly in the hands of the Commonwealth. Two-thirds of State government revenue is derived from Commonwealth grants and one-quarter of local government revenue is derived from Commonwealth grants, a situation which compares very unfavourably with the other great federations of the world when one looks at the figures for revenue in the provinces of Canada, and so on. This does not square up with the Government's professed aims of redistributing fiscal responsibility under its federalism policy. What we have in 1982 is a denial of everything that the Government said it was going to do in 1976.

The new federalism policy has basically failed for several reasons. It has failed because of a lack of consultation and co-operation. It has failed because of another monetarist ideological commitment of this Government which expressed itself in the slogan: 'Squeeze the public sector and the private sector will take up the slack'. Of course, what in fact has happened in Commonwealth-State relations is that, sure, the public sector has been squeezed but, like a blancmange, it is the Commonwealth sector which has felt the squeeze, and the State public sector has blown out in the six years of this Government since new federalism came into being. If one looks at the figures-I will seek leave to have them incorporated in Hansard-State public services have increased significantly between December 1975 and October 1981 from roughly 885,000 people to 1,012,000 people while the Commonwealth Public Service suffered a slight decline in 1978 and has increased slightly only in October 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: —So the Commonwealth should have shown more restraint?

—That is the problem, Senator. It really has been a phoney exercise because the restraint has been in monetary terms but not in terms of a shared ideological commitment about reducing the size of the public sector. That is where it has failed. I am not saying that there has been anything particularly evil about that; it is unfortunate for the Government, but I think that in fact is what has happened. TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, the other ideological strain which the new federalism ran into was the Government's commitment to monetarism. As Professor Mathews puts it again:

SPEECH.PARA: It has used its centralised financing powers to return to the thoroughly discredited policies of the great depression, involving acceptance of high levels of unemployment at the same time as urgent capital works are deferred for lack of funds.

That, of course, is a situation which profoundly affects the States. In my State of Victoria, for example, the hospitals are broke-a shocking situation for a State government facing an election on 3 April. But who put that Government to the jump? The Fraser Government put it to the jump. It is a mixture of State government incompetence and Fraser Government ideology that has resulted in that situation in Victoria. Similarly, things like school dental services are broke in Victoria. Dental services are being denied to kids in Victoria because of the ramifications of this policy.

Finally, there was concern to reduce the central power of government-a legitimate concern. The Government instead has ensured that it has maintained a tight, centralised, fiscal policy. Confusion reigns because of that as the Government has refused to acknowledge its responsibilities in areas such as health and education and restraints on public spending have resulted in cuts in essential public works and development, and massive unemployment-all of which, of course, affect the States as well. The Government has failed also to pursue a strongminded and rational policy on tax avoidance. This has added to its problems of revenue collection. Again, as Professor Mathews said, if the same enthusiasm were to be shown by the Commonwealth for controlling revenue collections as for controlling government expenditures-about which we heard a bit at Question Time today-higher rates of taxation would be unnecessary.

That again is an indictment of this Government's policies in this area. There has been an abandonment of government responsibility in whole areas of social services. There have been political deals with the States rather than a rational and responsible policy of fixed management, the $16m grant to Queensland last year being a classic example of a backdoor deal and not a consistent application of a policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, before developing the argument I think it is essential to clarify a few positions. First of all, Senator Button does not stand here today as a professed federalist who regrets that federalism has not been fully introduced. On the contrary, he stands here as the leader in this chamber of the Labor Party pledged to unqualified centralism. Let us get the thing right from the start. All the crocodile tears about whether a degree of federalism has been achieved are purely that and are being shed in the knowledge of the Loan Council meeting on Friday and with some hopes of some pickings in a Victorian election. But there will be none as we will see in the journey that we take.

SPEECH.PARA: To put this matter into true perspective one must first of all look at what was the situation before we introduced new federalism because one would think that what has happened now, rather than being an improvement, is some sort of disaster. I have quoted before in this place a very revered ex-Premier, a Labor Premier, Mr Dunstan. I will now use his words to describe for us in this place what the position was under the Whitlam Labor Government in terms of its policies of relationships with the States. Mr Dunstan addressed the State Convention of the Australian Labor Party on 16 June 1974 and he said this:
. . . . the Federal Government's policy-
That is, the Whitlam Government's policy-
was forcing State Governments into regressive tax measures.
He said:
Centralised decision-making from Canberra could spell 'disaster' for industries and workers in South Australia.
He went on to say:
Difficult though it may be to apply still further increases in the fields of State taxes, we will be forced again this year to levy additional revenues to finance services of an adequate standard.
He then said that a week before Mr Whitlam had informed him that:
. . . South Australia would get no more money than was prescribed in the tax reimbursement formula, although plainly it would be insufficient to meet the State's needs.
Mr Dunstan said:
The State has no means of reducing its expenditure markedly from revenue sources . . . .
I want honourable senators to take note of his next words. He said:

I believe it to be essential for the Labor Party to decide in Federal conference that the formula for provision of money to the States from Federal income tax should be an adequate and fixed percentage of income tax revenues to be returned to the States.

So, in summary what he said was that the Whitlam Government's relations with the States were disastrous, that it was forcing increased regressive taxes on the States, pressurising them, that the States were, in fact, forced to reduce their work and that the solution was to bring in a revenue-sharing system to the States. Mr Whitlam, who was then the leader, had been on public record in two prepared addresses to the nation stating his views. First of all he said-I paraphrase him-that the best thing that any Labor member of a State Parliament could do for Australia was to work for the destruction of that State Parliament. In other words, quite clearly Mr Whitlam said that the State parliaments ought to be destroyed. In another address he went further and said that he saw the abolition of State parliaments in Australia and that there would be one centralised government with great national powers over the economy and some provincial governments. This is the situation against which we start, a situation in which even the Labor Premiers condemned the Whitlam Government, a situation in which, day by day, the papers were full of dog fights between the Premiers and the Whitlam Government. Indeed, the Premiers did much to expose the dangers of the Whitlam Government. Mr Dunstan said that the right solution was revenue sharing on a fixed basis. That is fascinating because it is precisely what this Federal Government has done.

Let me point out what this new federalism is because there are three or four matters that ought to be kept in mind. Let me take local government as a start. Under the Whitlam Government local government was faced with an enormous squeeze , with great inflation rising to 17 per cent in the March quarter of 1975, and with interest rates rising. Local government in Australia found that even after putting up rates more and more it could do less and less work. Indeed, some local councils were increasing their rates by as much as 30 per cent a year under the Whitlam Government. The important thing is that this so-called government that is now in opposition advocating that we are doing wrong had dealt local government a crippling blow, a reduction in real money, a reduction in real services. What has this Government done under the new federalism? There is a great silence from Senator Button. It has revolutionised local government. For the first time, local government has been brought to the table as an equal of State and Federal government. For the first time, an advisory council for intergovernmental relations has been set up-

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is the chairman?

—On my advice, Professor Russell Mathews was appointed chairman of that body. So in fact for the first time the three levels of government-local, State and Federal-sit around a table discussing the matters of importance. Indeed, if anyone wants to sneer let them go to a local government conference and knock it. I tell Senator Button and Senator Walsh, who are now sneering, that local government regards this as one of the great breakthroughs in reform for local government in Australia. Furthermore, whereas local government was bedevilled by tied grants before the Federal Government introduced a system of revenue sharing for local government, it now gets 2 per cent of Commonwealth revenue untied. What has happened is that local government has been freed from the tied grants of the Whitlam Labor Government and has been able, under our administration, to modify and mitigate its rates and to get on with its programs.
—Not my rates. Are your rates mitigated?

—Senator Button probably lives under a Labor Council. That, of course, is his sorrow. Would Senator Button have the strictures imposed on local government that were imposed upon them under the Whitlam Administration or local government as it is today? Ask local government that. The rhetoric of Senator Button regarding State governments was very interesting. He said that the States had had a raw deal, that they had been squeezed. He said, quite rightly, that the States had in fact been able to increase the number of their public servants by over a hundred thousand while the Commonwealth had reduced its number of public servants by in the order of 10,000. He said that was a squeeze.
—I did not say that. That is not true. Your figures are all wrong .

—Well, the figures are in that order of proportion. The numbers may be more than that. The fact is that Senator Button said that there was a demonstration of a squeeze. In the first five years of the Fraser Government every State government in this country was able, year by year, to introduce and to implement major tax cuts and to expand its programs. How was that a squeeze if they had, in fact, more money than they needed and were giving it back to the community? State governments have even abolished probate-a thing that the Federal Labor Party would deplore. After all, Senator Walsh is on record as indicating that he would like to reinstate death duties at the Federal level. A Labor government would want to get at the estates of the dead. Of course it would. But State by State, States were able to reduce taxation and expand their functions. So where was the squeeze? It was said that the States did not have any real powers passed over to them, that this was more a centralisation. I remember very well the debate over days in this place on the off-shore petroleum and mineral legislation. How much we remember that this Government said that, although the powers in that respect had been clearly centralised in Canberra by the High Court, we would voluntarily cede the powers to the States by legislation. The boys who are now crying crocodile tears about federalism were then saying: 'You must not do this. We want to clutch the powers '. They were talking Whitlamism-the best thing that a Labor member of a State parliament can do is to work for the destruction of the State Parliament. Senator Button has the nerve to talk about the Victorian election when his own leader was out to destroy the Victorian State Parliament.
—Who are you talking about now?

—I am talking about Mr Whitlam. No doubt now honourable senators opposite wish that he had never said these things. No doubt they would like to forget that in Victoria, under a new leader, Labor supporters are nervously saying: 'Let us see whether we can promote Mr Wran as an alternative. Let us have a Wran-type of government in Victoria'. With a Wran-type of government in Victoria there would be twice as many strikes. It would be like New South Wales. As the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has said, New South Wales is the strike capital of Australia. Almost half of the working days lost in Australia are lost in New South Wales. By any measure the Liberal Government in Victoria is a progressive government. It has a surplus of electric power to expand its industries. It is able to get the New South Wales Government out of its mortgage. Yet here Senator Button is trying to take a quick trick by saying that on 3 April there will be judgment on this situation.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the situation. We are asked to compare this Government with the three years of Whitlamism, the professed policies of which were to destroy State and local government. It is quite clear from the statements of Mr Whitlam that he did not believe in State governments at all. Local government was forced into penury, as was State government, based upon what Mr Dunstan said. Can honourable senators opposite deny what he said? Was he wrong when he said those things I have quoted? The silence is a beautiful answer. They cannot deny what Mr Dunstan said because they have said that he was the model on this thing. So, he was right when he said that the real solution is tax sharing-a fixed percentage of the tax. What have we done? We have given the States a fixed percentage of the tax. So, one by one we go down this road. Have we given a raw deal to the States ? It was Dunstan who said that the States were getting a raw deal under the Labor Government-the Hayden-Whitlam Government-which was reducing the States' services and putting on regressive taxation so that the States were being strangled. There is a time warp in Senator Button's mind because he described perfectly what happened then.

He then talked about the squeeze on the States that was happening under this Government. He said that the States were having to take on more and more public servants while we took on fewer but the States, on the other hand, did not have the money. In fact, I have reminded the Parliament that year by year not only did they have the money to do that but they had surplus money. They went from deficit budgeting under Labor to a surplus whereby they could cut taxation. Let us keep a little in mind this question that has been raised about whether we have strangled the States. The suggestion is that we have forced them to do more but not given them more money. I have demonstrated what has happened to the off- shore petroleum legislation. But much more has happened. Many functions have been passed to the States and absorbed and, along with that, an appropriate amount of money-the amount that the Commonwealth has been spending-has been absorbed into the formula so that the States have the money to undertake the functions. Under Labor year by year the percentage of specific purpose grants increased relative to general purpose grants. In other words, under Labor more and more the States were being told: 'Here is your money and you have to do this with it', and less and less were they being told: 'Here is some money untied', until the ratio was almost 50-50. Bit by bit we have reversed that trend until today the general purpose payments to the States constitute 67 per cent of all revenue passed to the States and only 33 per cent of it is tied-a vast reversal of what has happened in the past.

One would think that Professor Mathews was making an indictment on this matter. What a strange thing for honourable senators opposite to call him their disciple when he is an avowed federalist to his back teeth and they are avowed and professed centralists pledged to have all power in Canberra. Day after day, week after week and year after year they have always said here that it is absolutely wrong for the States to be asked to raise taxes. They are opposed to that. It is worth noting, for instance, that Professor Mathews in his criticisms said that Mr Wran had said that there would be no increase in the rate of any New South Wales tax for the fifth consecutive year and that the States preferred to leave the bulk of their revenue raising to the Commonwealth. First of all, Mr Wran has given the lie to Senator Button's claim of a squeeze. There has been no increase in the rate of any New South Wales tax for the fifth consecutive year and yet New South Wales has been able to expand its public service. But the important thing is that Mr Wran said that the States have preferred to leave the bulk of their revenue raising to the Commonwealth. In other words, even though the federalism provisions were given to them, they preferred not to use them. Professor Mathews went on to say that one of the fundamental difficulties was that it appeared that the States either could not or would not exercise their revenue raising powers, although they have the facilities to do so.

There is a fundamental error of belief in this country, a belief that was engendered by the Whitlam-Hayden Labor Government. That is the belief that the Commonwealth has all the money-it is the rich man-and that the States have no money, they are poor. I want all Australians to get in their minds the simple fact that of all public finance spent in Australia, of all the money taken out of the taxpayers' pockets and spent in Australia, 52 per cent is spent by the States and local government and only 48 per cent is spent by the Commonwealth. So, in fact the Commonwealth is the minority spender of money and the States are the bigger spenders of money.

Let me knock Senator Button's propositions one by one. What nerve to say that we have not done enough on the journey to federalism when in fact Senator Button and his party are professed centralists. What nerve to say that when in fact the Whitlam Goverment was the greatest centraliser, the greatest distorter of federalism there was. What nerve, in the face of what Mr Dunstan said, to cite figures on the capacity of the States to increase their staff without also citing figures on their capacity to cut taxes and, therefore, revealing their surplus of money over the years. But none of these things are said. How could honourable senators opposite forget this Government's revolutionary and great reforms of local government? We have had a great opportunity to contrast how Hayden, Whitlam and Button did it and how we are doing it, and I know how the public will judge.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is appropriate that the Senate should be discussing Commonwealth-State relationships. The matter of public importance before the Senate deals with the failure of new federalism. We are concerned not with going back to 1973, 1974 or 1975 but with making the necessary comparisons between the events that now characterise themselves in Premiers Conferences. This coming Friday the Premiers Conference will be held here in Canberra. We will see another one of the festering sores of the Liberal- National Country Parties performance. We will see again the sort of divisiveness flowing from that Conference, which has been marked by similar instances over the last couple of years. We are, of course, concerned about the unsatisfactory, inequitable and disorganised state of Federal-State financial and other relationships. That is why we believe that we ought to be discussing today the failure of the Fraser Government's federalism policy. It is a policy that originated in the mind of Senator Carrick and was taken on board by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). It became a central plank of the Fraser Government 's policy for the 1975 and 1977 elections but, interestingly enough, it was forgotten in the 1980 election.

SPEECH.PARA: When in Opposition in September 1975 Mr Fraser promised that if he were elected to government he would introduce a new form of Federal-State financial relations . He put this in a rather grandiose setting. He talked about the need to protect individual freedoms and States' rights and the need to provide an effective barrier against authoritarian centralist control. Those are terms with which Senator Carrick regaled us through the years 1975, 1976 particularly and 1977. But he has not done so in more recent times because even he, if he were to look at this matter objectively, would have to say that the federalism policies of the Fraser Government are in tatters. Senator Carrick and Mr Fraser tried to create the impression that this new form of Federal-State financial relations would enable States to be freer of central control than was previously the case. To those ends Mr Fraser proposed, firstly, to give the States a set percentage of income tax for revenue purposes and, secondly, to allow the States to impose an income tax surcharge-in theory to give a rebate. It is interesting that stage 2 of the new federalism policy has never been implemented, largely because of the reluctance and the refusal of the States to become involved in that stage. Mr Fraser in his policy document of September 1975 said that these measures would do the following:
. . . ensure that the States will have substantially the financial capacity to meet their financial responsibilities.

Of course, State and local governments, being closer to the people, are involved in the processes of providing services to the people. It was proper in those circumstances, having regard to the wealth of this country, that the States should be increasing their services to the Australian people, because that is what the Australian people want and demand of their State and local authorities. The Prime Minister was clearly saying that the new kind of financial relationships would enable the States to be better able to look after themselves financially than had previously been the case. It has now become clear to all but the most partial observers that the Fraser-Carrick new federalism is a fraud . Under the cover of this highblown rhetoric which we often hear spoken in the Senate by Senator Carrick and in another place by Mr Fraser they have attempted to do three things. They have attempted to shift the responsibility for social programs-that is, programs that benefit the ordinary people-back to the States. They have attempted to force the States to raise their own revenue for programs while cutting back on Commonwealth grants. The much talked about Federal deficit has therefore been transferred to the States. Who can deny that every State government in our Commonwealth today is having difficulty in meeting the services demanded by the citizens in the respective States?

Through manipulating the Federal-State tax sharing arrangements the Government has sought to control more tightly the economic policies of the State governments. This is the very reverse of the claim it made in 1975. Have we not seen evidence of the Treasurer and the Prime Minister seeking to determine the development programs of the State governments, in particular those of my State of New South Wales? In fact, Mr Fraser's dose of new federalism has neglected areas of social need, eroded the chances for an equitable distribution of taxation, reduced Australian planning and control of resource development-surely that is the responsibility of a national government-fragmented the Australian social and economic scene and driven the State Premiers into firm opposition to the Australian Government and its policies. There is not a Premier anywhere in Australia who is satisfied with the programs imposed upon him by the financial policies of the Fraser Administration. When Mr Fraser first unveiled his new federalism policy, the non-Labor Premiers hailed it, looking forward to, as they said in a joint statement:
. . . a new era of Commonwealth-State co-operation.

Is that what they are saying today? I think Senator Button referred to them as slow thinkers. I would refer to them as slow learners. It has taken them a number of years to wake up to the problems imposed upon them by the Federal Government. They are coming to the Premiers Conference for another confrontation this Friday. In their most recent Budgets at least two Liberal State governments made clear what they thought of Fraser's new federalism. I must say in relation to my State that the Premier, Mr Wran, was the one who refused to accept the guidelines of the new federalism policy and who said that he would not introduce new taxes as was required under the implementation of stage 2 of that program. What of Mr Tonkin from South Australia? He provides one example of his thinking in his 1981-82 Budget statement. He said:

The Commonwealth Budget for 1981-82 shows an increase of only 8 per cent in funds for the States, which is well below the current and expected level of inflation. That increase compares with a very high increase of 15 per cent ( almost double the rate of increase to the States) on expenditures for Commonwealth purposes.
The contrast is stark. The Commonwealth's success in restraining its expenditures has been achieved at the expense of the States.
He then went on to say:
Regrettably . . . the restraints I have just mentioned have made it necessary to adjust some rates of taxation . . .

So the States have been forced to increase the taxes and charges imposed upon their own citizens. In Victoria, Mr Thompson's Budget statement was no less blunt. Referring to the States' submissions to the Federal Government for sufficient funds to cover programs, it reads:

No response was received from the Commonwealth until the Premiers Conference on 4 May 1981, when the State premiers were presented virtually with a fait accompli which was to apply in 1981-82 and which represented a substantial reduction in the reasonable expectations of the States for that year. Thus, because of the cessation of the tax-sharing formula, the determination of the States' tax-sharing entitlement for 1981-82 was reached in a series of separate negotiated steps, with the decisions resting finally with the Commonwealth.

We all know of the big steal by the Commonwealth of $70m of the States' funds, to which Senator Button referred. Of course, that, as Senator Button sought to show, is what we are seeking to compare. We are not seeking to deal with something that happened seven, eight or nine years ago but what is happening currently in relationships between the Commonwealth and the States. So there we have Fraser's federalism in a nutshell, described by Liberals, by Fraser's own people, his own supporters. They describe a system of Federal-State relationships which rips off the States, rips off the people and attempts to absolve the Federal Government of responsibility while in reality putting the strings of control in Federal hands insofar as we have the purse strings here in Canberra. Is it any wonder therefore that the State Premiers will come to Canberra this Friday ready for a bloody battle? Is it any wonder that we are to have another example of confrontation between the six States as they unite against the Commonwealth's policies and against the Commonwealth dictating to them the way in which their social programs shall be developed and the way in which their development programs shall be curtailed?

If we are to liken Federal-State relationships these days to a battle, then we must look for the casualties struck down in the fight which is now synomynous with the annual meetings of the Premiers Conference. There are casualties. They can be found amongst the homeless who have been struck down by the $526.4m cut in real net payments to the States for housing. I will not quote the New South Wales Minister for Housing, but I remind honourable senators of the statements made by the Victorian Minister for Housing, Mr Kennett, in his trenchant, consistent and strong criticism of the policies of the Commonwealth in the area of public housing. Of course, these facts were left alone in the debate. All Senator Carrick can do is to try to turn the clock back. Perhaps we paid for our sins in 1975 but the Government will certainly pay for its sins in 1983; make no mistake about it. The States will not be on the Government's side, whatever the colour of their political representation.

Who are the others who have lost out? They can be found amongst those forced to pay increased State charges through the system of double taxation forced upon them by Mr Fraser's federalism. I admit that the New South Wales Government was able to take special steps to extend its services and avoid increases in State taxes by using some of the reserves that have been accumulated over many years. That resulted from good housekeeping and good business acumen being applied. But that moment has passed and they are now confronted with a reduction in services or a squeeze on the Federal Government for more funds. We can look amongst those who have lost out because of the 29 per cent real cut in capital funds for the States since 1975-76. Almost a third has been cut from the capital funds from which the States have to finance their capital works programs. As has been pointed out in previous debates, the public works programs are carried out largely by private contractors. It is no wonder, therefore, that the economy is in the state that it is in today.

What about those who need assistance under the special purpose grants for the States? Those grants were reduced by 16.1 per cent in the most recent Budget. The Government claims-Senator Carrick repeats it-that this cut is in untied grants. But the facts tell a different story. In truth, the responsibility for housing, health, social welfare and Aboriginal advancement is palmed off to the States. It is no wonder that Australia's foremost expert in Federal-State relationships, Professor Russell Mathews, recently described the present state of affairs as:
. . . a shambles where there once was a system.
The Government has, he said:

. . . used its centralised financing powers to return to the thoroughly discredited policies of the Great Depression, involving acceptance of high levels of unemployment at the same time as urgent capital works are deferred for lack of funds.

When will this Government take notice of the State Premiers and these sorts of experts? When will it respond to the needs of Australia's people? I turn briefly again to the metaphor of the battle in describing Federal-State relationships. We have seen the casualties in this battle, but who are the victors? In line with the Government's resource development mania-a mania which daily is becoming more and more unreal as we see the boom disintegrating-the victors are the resource rich States, the mining regions and the mining giants. In passing back to the states key responsibilities -as President Reagan is currently trying to do-such as the ability to levy charges or to abolish them, the policy of new federalism is leaving the way open for States to see who can offer the most concessions to the mining giants and who can give them the most tempting invitation to exploit the mineral wealth of the States. We see resource rich States such as Queensland and Western Australia bending over backwards to lock themselves into the international economy and to be the resource base for that economy. They are succeeding in doing it with the full support of the pass-the- buck policy of the new federalism of Fraser and Carrick.

At what cost is this happening? Firstly, it is at the cost of revenue for Australia, as recent studies at the Australian National University centre of economic policy research show. They show that ad hoc, inconsistent, rival and duplicate systems of State and Federal resource taxing result in a real reduction of the revenue that could be collected for public use under a planned and national system.
