TALK.START.PARA: —This year and in the preceding years of the Fraser Government the people of Australia have recognised the importance it has placed on bringing power and decisions back to the people; bringing those matters that can be decided at the local level to local government; bringing those matters that are best decided at the State level to State government; and limiting the amount of bureaucracy, power and decision making in this distant, centralised place of Canberra. That imaginative and important emphasis of the Fraser Liberal program has been recognised by the people of Australia and endorsed by them, notably in the election of 1975 and in subsequent elections. The Opposition is now trying to tap in to that popular support for new federalism. In feint and crocodile tear ways it is trying to lament that not quite all of it has been fulfilled.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard two shadow Ministers of the Australian Labor Party, the Opposition in the Senate chamber, speaking at length about federalism. Not once have they taken away any jot or tittle of the Labor Party's commitment to centralism. They had every opportunity over two long-ranging, well thought out, prepared speeches to start to deny the Labor Party's enduring commitment to centralism, the destruction of the States, the destruction even of local governments and the destruction of the Senate. That is the Labor Party's commitment and not once did either of the shadow Ministers dare to trespass upon the Caucus commitment to centralism. In those speeches we have seen a quite hypocritical attack upon the Government. The shadow Ministers tried to allege that the prospect of new federalism, the bringing of power back to the people under the Fraser Government, has gone only 90 per cent of the way. It has, of course, been a magnificent change recognised by the people of Australia but it has not gone quite all of the way. Those speakers, from their distant, centralist position, have tried to give a little enlightenment in the development of this popular policy. Even Senator Button, who said that he personally, despite Caucus, saw very real merits in federalism and in bringing power back to the people, was not able to sustain that personal preference and commitment which is not popular in the centralist Caucus of the Opposition.

Perhaps those people of Australia interested in this periodic debate will note the tired arguments of the Opposition. They are more tired of it this year than they were before because the Opposition is missing Senator Wriedt. He had a particular interest in this matter. As one Liberal senator with a very strong interest in the implementation of Fraser-Carrick federalism-as it was put by the Opposition-I was very interested to hear the arguments that Senator Wriedt put forward in the past. They were put forward with much more knowledge and interest than were the feint speeches that we heard today. But even Senator Wriedt was not convincing in his jumbled arithmetic. He was not able to lead even me, an interested listener in the Senate, to the logic or the bottom line of his arguments. He tried to say that federalism was being implemented but not to the fullest extent or to the advantage of some of the growing rich and fat State governments. The speeches we have heard from the Opposition today, even after Senator Wriedt's lame-approach attack on the Government, are very tired indeed. I am all the more convinced that we are hearing a load of tired rhetoric because a premiers conference is coming up this week in Canberra and perhaps Opposition senators may try to attach some criticism to the Fraser Government.

What has been the import of new federalism? As all Australians who are interested in politics know, the States, having sovereign governments, ceded specific powers under the terms of the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia. When this Commonwealth was formed at the beginning of this century specific named powers and responsibilities were given to the Commonwealth Parliament. Sovereignty for the remaining powers remained with the States and this is the federalist structure. We are not a unitary state such as New Zealand or the United Kingdom; we are a state which is made up of independent sovereign States such as South Australia, New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania and so on. Each State has ceded particular powers to the Commonwealth. That is not a centralist system; that is a system where defined and restricted powers come to the centre; sovereignty is, in the main, kept by the States. That is what we call federalism.

However, particularly during the Whitlam Labor period, this constitutional foundation for Australian Government, in balance between Canberra and the States , was totally upset. The Whitlam Government, by aggrandisement brought more and more powers to itself and kept the responsibility of making more and more decisions, by government Ministers and the ever increasing bureaucracy that developed during those years, here in Canberra. The people of Australia found it difficult to get to those who made the decisions. Not every Australian, in remote country areas or even in suburbs and cities of our capitals, was able to have access to the decision-makers in this increasingly Whitlam centralised Canberra. With popular insistence the Liberal Party came back to reassert its own foundation of political philosophy, a true federalism; it decentralised power to local and State centres. This resurgence of federalism was called 'new federalism'.

For this leadership Senator Button has given responsibility to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Leader of the Government in this chamber, Senator Sir John Carrick. Senator Carrick was described by Senator Button as the leading intellectual of the Liberal Party. That may well be the case. Certainly at that time, amongst the shadow Ministers who determined the kinds of remedies that were important for Australia, Senator Carrick had the responsibility for this important question of Federal-State relations. With his experience as general secretary of the Liberal Party in New South Wales, his direct knowledge of the affairs of the New South Wales Parliament and Government and also his experience here in the Commonwealth, he was ideally placed to reassert what was all along the Liberal emphasis upon a proper balance in the distribution of powers in Australia. I think that the Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, and Senator Carrick, have been rightly named by the Opposition as the leaders, the authors, of this particular emphasis.

At that time I was not a senator. I was the policy co-ordinator of the Liberal Party in my own State of South Australia and I welcomed the clarity and intellectual analysis in these implications of federalism which were very clearly set out in those years. Since I have been a senator in this place, in the last four years, I have been one of the strongest supporters of that clear statement of the Liberal position which was set out in 1975. What has been done has already been set out by Senator Carrick in his speech today. Local government has never before had such a high proportion of public revenue. In real terms the amount of Commonwealth money given to local government in every part of Australia has more than doubled. The principle behind that was set out in a slogan or phrase. The Fraser Government made a direct promise that 2 per cent of personal income taxation was the goal that we would strive for to make sure that local government had the finance to achieve the decisions that were appropriate in the local area. And we did achieve that goal. We have achieved that enormous growth in disbursement of public money to local government.

Senator Button contradicted himself when he, I think, used the word 'blancmange ' in the sense that there was a kind of squeezing out of the State Public Service and revenue throughout the 1970s. We have been so committed to ensuring the financial foundation of the States that perhaps even the generous policies of the Fraser Government have gone beyond what may have been best in terms of allowing some blowout of State Governments. During the last year or two I, as a Liberal senator, have welcomed the restraint that the Treasurer, Mr Howard, and the Prime Minister and others involved in Premiers Conferences have shown. That restraint is a direct reflection of the policies on which this Government was elected in 1975, 1977 and 1980. I believe we should take that matter seriously. We should not allow Government expenditure in every field, not least the States, which is still the biggest area in Commonwealth Government spending after social security, to be unrestrained.

I believe that to fulfil the responsible economic policies that have been clearly set forth by the Fraser Government there must be restraint at Premiers Conferences. Whatever arguments are put by the States for infrastructure financing, through loan accounts or through the direct share of Commonwealth revenue, whilst the Fraser Government, I believe, has had a record of listening most carefully and of truly consulting with the States at Premiers Conferences, there must be an overall perspective of restraint along with all of the other areas of Government spending.

I will refer to a few concrete examples that have not been touched on by Senator Carrick. One is the quarantine arrangements in Australia. The Whitlam Government had a report which recommended centralising quarantine literally to fulfil the responsibility of the Commonwealth, it being responsible for this area. However, it is important for State experts to have a direct involvement in quarantine. Therefore we ensured, by consultation with the States, that State agricultural department officers and veterinarians are directly involved in fulfilling the quarantine functions of the Commonwealth.

I could give other such examples relating to the health package. Many have commended the Commonwealth Government's recent health package. I call it the MacKellar health package because the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) was most careful in pulling together the different elements of it for Cabinet approval. The health package policy that now operates in Australia was most mindful of new federalism. It was mindful of the importance of bringing responsibilities as far as possible to the States. I could talk about education and about roads. In the past we had seven categories of roads. We determined every sort of road and the allocation of funds to each category. The number of categories has now been reduced to three. I could go on and say that we could do more towards new federalism for example, in the area of childhood services, and even in some aspects of arts funding such as the Dix report recommends about music. I totally reject the Opposition's accusations about any failure of new federalism and assert that this Government must continue on the path of decentralising power and bringing close to the people decisions and responsibilities that can be close to the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been a somewhat fascinating debate on Senator Button's matter of public importance relating to the failure of new federalism. I was rather surprised, however, to hear Senator Teague, given his professional background, say that the Liberal Party had invented the phrase 'new federalism'. He should know as well as I do that 'new federalism' was used in relation to the New Deal of President Roosevelt. Therefore, in this debate with nothing to go on other than the fact that we are talking about the failure of new federalism, I think we must look at the record of the Australian Labor Party's new federalism policy and the Liberal party's new federalism policy.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset, it seems to me to be a sham debate today. I think probably most people have accepted-certainly political scientists in this country have accepted-that new federalism is purely a tactical expression used in the competitive struggle to win national power. Other than that, it has very little to recommend it. The particular aspect of new federalism that people have been concerned about relates basically to the share of revenue that is available at the various levels of government. That is the argument that must be entered into . We wholeheartedly support the Liberal Party's new federalism policy in that it sets out, basically, that there should be greater involvement on the part of the States in the raising and expenditure of revenue.

The legislation which was passed in 1978 allowing the States to impose a percentage surcharge or to allow a percentage rebate on personal income tax has not been taken up by the States. The problem in relation to federalism is not one that is confined to the Federal level. Indeed, it is a malaise for both the Federal Government and the State governments. The Australian Democrats hold quite firmly to the view that those areas for which either of those levels of government has responsibility would be best served by allowing the government responsible to raise taxes to pay for them. In other words, at the moment we probably have the worst of all possible worlds. At election time there is confusion in the minds of the electors as to who is responsible. The Federal Government, in a Federal election, is able to blame the States for many of the ills that it has caused. Likewise, in State elections, such as the one currently under way, the State governments are able to blame the Federal Government for the problems which are really of their own making. That particular brand of federalism is probably the worst that we could have devised.

If we go back to the beginning of federation, we find that the three major problems in the conventions in relation to finance were those relating to tariffs, the inequitable economic power of the States which were going to enter into federation and the emerging problem that the various Crown colonies saw of the relationship between the Commonwealth Government and the States. Those three problems are still with us. They are still the major political and economic problems on our plate in 1982. We have the problem of tariffs, the problem of the resources being differentially spread out throughout Australia-I refer particularly to the resource rich States-and the problem of disbursement of funds between the Commonwealth, the States and local government.

I suggest that the lauding that the Liberal party has given to its own version of a new federalism and its claim that local government authorities are very happy with it has very little to do with reality. If one takes the time and effort to travel as I have travelled in the last few months throughout one's State talking to shire clerks about the problems of their local areas, one will discover that one of the major problems is of a Federal making. It relates to a new policy in relation to roads and the fact that road moneys, instead of being funnelled to the shires, are being funnelled to private enterprise for the building of Federal roads in their areas. This is causing extraordinary difficulties in many of the small towns in country areas.

I do not know whether people have ever bothered to look at the figures in relation to that but in one shire that I visited two weeks ago 30 men will have to be put off because the shire could not possibly enter into the types of competitive arrangements that private enterprise can enter into. The shire clerk said that the shire was not able to enter into such arrangements because it had to be responsible to its ratepayers. If this shire puts off 30 people it will lose 30 people from the main town in the shire. That will be 10 per cent of the population of that town. That is what we mean when we talk about decentralisation, the fundamental political element in federalism. That is what the whole federal system is about-the notion of having effective decentralisation.

Every policy that goes through this Parliament should be looked at, not only in terms of a particular political ideology, but also in terms of what it may be able to do to strengthen federalism and to strengthen, in particular, decentralisation in this country. It is only by effective policies for decentralisation-not the types that we have seen in the last few years-that we will be able to maintain the people who currently live in the country and rural areas of this nation, and it is hoped that we will be able to start reversing the trend and build up again the population in country areas. That is absolutely vital and essential for the health and well-being of this country. We must look at every policy that goes through this place in those terms as well as in terms of the political ideology of the party that is ruling at any time.

The tax legislation that I mentioned enabling State governments to raise taxes was attacked very strongly by the States. The States said that they did not want a bar of raising their own personal income taxes. What they did not allude to in that Bill, which was a Liberal Government sponsored Bill, was that they were also given the opportunity to grant a percentage rebate. In other words, the States said that they did not want to buy into that because if they did the odium for raising taxes would fall on them. In other words, they were not willing to come into a true federalism. They were fairly happy to remain in their existing shambles. In that they have been aided by the present Federal Government.

Although it was one of its own Bills which permitted the States to raise or lower percentage income taxes, this Federal Government did not provide room to allow the States to take advantage of that. It gave the States a very good excuse for not taking on their responsibilities. We have a stalemate, a situation in which the central Government is constantly taking unto itself more and more power. It is a situation in which State governments are unwilling to take back the powers that they should take back and should exercise. But unless there is reasonable fiscal reform in relation to the amount of tax that the Federal Government wishes and continues to levy-I refer to the enormous increase , for example, of $5.5m in income tax in this financial year-where is the room for a developing federalism?

The elements which have been discussed in the Senate so far in this session come together on this policy. It is still of fundamental concern to try to have developed in this country a rational and reasonable Federal system. The division of power which was seen as so necessary in the last century is even more necessary now. The Australian Democrats are very firmly a federalist party, a decentralist party. If those decentralisation policies are to be put into operation a central government must make room for them. It must enable State governments to take advantage of those Bills that the Liberal Government has proposed. In other words, it must be very careful while talking about new federalism to have policies which enable new federalism to operate.

There is a very revealing parallel between Whitlam's new federalism and the new federalism of the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser. The new federalism talked about in those articles by Mr Whitlam prior to the Labor Party coming to power changed during the period it was in power to a policy of more and more power being taken by the central Government. But if one looks at the policies that were proposed beforehand one sees that while the Labor Government talked about new federalism its policies very clearly pointed to a centralisation of power. In other words, one of the things one might be able to say for the Labor Government at that time is that it attempted to achieve the things it was talking about in terms of centralisation.

One of the problems with which one is faced with Liberal rhetoric is that whilst the Liberals still talk about it we are still heading in the opposite direction; we are still heading towards centralisation. What is very difficult to determine from what the Government spokesmen have said today is whether this was the original intention of the Government or whether it just happened. New federalism is pure rhetoric. Over the last 10 years, since 1972, it was probably never meant to be anything else. It is probably the type of policy which can be sold to the electorate on the suggestion that the encroachment of centralising power be constantly attacked. That goes down well in the electorate, but whether there has ever been any intention on the part of either the Liberal-National Country Party coalition or the Labor Party to do anything effective and useful about it is probably as much the guess of anybody in the electorate as it is the guess of those respective party leaders. We would strongly support the bringing forward of any legislation which effectively centralised power, which effectively gave power back to the lower or higher levels, however one likes to put it, of the Australian community, which gave local government a much more effective and incisive input into finances and which made States responsible not only for programs but also for raising the revenue to finance those programs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate is about the alleged failure of the new federalism. I suppose the best way to deal with that matter at the outset is to refer the Senate to some figures that appeared in the 1981 Commonwealth Grants Commission report on State Tax Sharing Entitlements. I will cite the figures for only New South Wales and South Australia in this context. I refer to page 37 of that document below the heading 'Formula Entitlements'. In 1974-75 New South Wales received $737.522m and South Australia received $261. 737m. In 1979-80 New South Wales received $1,663.467m compared with $737m in 1974-75. South Australia received $630.392m compared with $261.737m in 1974-75. I do not think that is pure rhetoric at all; it is pure fact, and that is what we ought to be considering here today.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin mentioned the 1971 Whitlam paper on new federalism. I should have thought it would be more appropriate to style that new centralism because one of the first things that the Whitlam Goverment embarked upon was an attempt to destroy local government as we know it today in favour of the development of 40-odd regional areas that would be subject to centralised control from Canberra . In other words, if a local government wanted to buy a grader, for example, it would have to refer it to Canberra before that expenditure could be authorised. As far as I am concerned that is totally wrong and is not at all in the spirit of what we regard as federalism.
Mr Fraser, when talking in the debate on the Review of Commonwealth Functions in April last year, said:

Only individuals have full knowledge of their own needs, wants and priorities; politicians, officials and bureaucrats neither have this knowledge nor can ever have it. This is why government must not be intrusive and why strong and efficient government must not grow into big and bureaucratic government.
Big government concentrates power, loses a perspective on its own limitations, and leaves less room for people to make their own choices.
And we must not forget that it is people, their knowledge and their talents, their enterprise and their determination, their belief that they can succeed, who have built Australia.

Contrary to what has been suggested by Opposition speakers, the spirit of federalism is to put into the hands of State and local governments a greater capacity to deal with their own affairs and to give them more responsibility. We would like to encourage them to follow the example of the Federal Government under Prime Minister Fraser with respect to curtailing and reducing public expenditure in an attempt to transfer the emphasis to the private sector. I believe that the Government is pursuing a course which is of benefit to the whole nation. When Senator Macklin was referring to the high rate of personal income tax I heard Senator Mason suggest by way of interjection that we ought to reduce personal income tax. I am sure that is the objective of the Government. The Australian Democrats really make me laugh when they talk about reducing personal income tax. Their continual errors of judgment, as they call them, are making this Government face a situation in which our revenue will be reduced. I refer to their threat to deny the Government the sales tax legislation. This will slow down the capacity of the Federal Government to reduce personal income taxes. We all realise they are too high, and the objective of the Government is to reduce that imposition.

Another matter that I referred to only yesterday was the suggestion that the Australian Democrats intend to deny the Government the oil levy Bill. The Government has encouraged private enterprise to step up its drilling operations. these operations will be doubled during the next 12 months at a cost of something like $800m. But no, the Democrats would like to provide these companies with a $45m windfall profit, denying that revenue to the Government and again slowing down the process of the Government being able to reduce personal income tax. Already the delay in implementing sales tax has cost the Government $80m in revenue. I think the Democrats must face the fact that they are deluding the people and are, in effect, holding a gun at the Government's head to get their own way with respect to certain elements of the sales tax Bills.

I believe that the Government's intentions are to pursue federalism as it has in the past. The figures show that this has been successful. I believe that the Federal Opposition is determined to pursue a course which would mean the weakening of the State governments. Of course, that was the object of the Whitlam Government when it was going to establish regional local government areas. That, of course, was to be the forerunner to the abolition of the States. This is quite clear from what Mr Hawke said in the Boyer lectures in 1979. He clearly advocated the abolition of the States when he said:
The perpetration of this anachronistic lunacy is hurting Australians every day of the week.

The Australian Labor Party that seems keen to do away with a federal system would do well to bear in mind the views of Dr Frohnmayer, Professor of Law at the University of Oregon, when he warned on the Australian Broadcasting Commission program Guest of Honour in January 1981:

Despite four decades of governmental centralisation the achievement of congressional supremacy and the expansion of national power in the United States , new voices there argue that the Federal principle does not have lasting significance.
Pointing to similarities between the revival in federalist policies in Australia and in the United States he stated:

PROCTEXT.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 to alter the restrictions on the broadcasting and televising of election matter in an election.
Bill presented, and-by leave-read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill proposes to eliminate the following from the Broadcasting and Television Act of 1942-73. Sub-section 4 and 4A in section 116 which read:

'(4) Subject to the next succeeding sub-section, the Commission or a licensee shall not, at any time between the end of an election period and the close of the poll on the day on which the election is held, broadcast or televise election matter.
(4A) Where, in respect of-
(a) an election of a member of the House of Representatives that is not a general election; or
(b) an election of a member or members of a House of the Parliament of a State,

The Board is of the opinion that programs broadcast from a particular broadcasting station or televised from a particular television station are not ordinarily received in the part of the Commonwealth to which the election relates, the Board may, by notice in writing served on or sent by post to the Commission or the licensee of the station, as the case requires, exempt the Commission or the licensee, as the case requires, from compliance with the last preceding sub-section in respect of the broadcasting or televising from that station of election matter relating to that election.'
It would also be necessary to eliminate that phrase ''the Wednesday next preceding'' from the definition of ''election period'' in sub-section (6).

This particular recommendation to have a pre-election 'blackout' was proposed simultaneously in March 1942 by the Joint Committee on Wireless Broadcasting ( the Gibson Committee) and by Arthur Calwell who was Minister for Information.

The Gibson Committee's recommendation was that: 'the Act should be amended to provide for . . . Wednesday night preceding an election day to be the last permissible occasion for the broadcasting of a political speech before that election day . . .'
(Recommendation 38)
In support of its position, the Gibson Committee provided he following rationale:

'. . . it might be argued that the field of broadcasting should be as free as that of the newspaper world, where unrestricted licence, subject only to the possibility of libel action, is the condition which obtains at all times. But commercial broadcasting can be more easily controlled than newspapers and in any case, there is no reason why the public should be asked to accept anything less than the highest possible ethical standard that can be attained by those who hold commercial broadcasting licences.
Furthermore broadcasting is a virtual monopoly, whereas the publication of newspapers is not'.
(Paragraph 408)
To reinforce its position it argued:

'In making our recommendation on this phase of broadcasting, we are not desirous of discouraging political-mindedness; on the contrary we feel that an enlightened and informed electorate is the best safeguard for the successful operation of democratic forms of government.'

In urging the adoption of the Canadian practice, that all broadcasts shall cease for a period before election day, we desire to establish what might be called a 'breathing space' which will make more difficult the snatching of victory by any one party in a manner that might do incalculable national harm.'
(Paragraphs 410, 411)
The idea of the pre-election 'breathing space' was foreshadowed earlier in the report at which point the committee drew in another factor to justify its attitude:

'It seems to us that if all political broadcasts concluded on the Wednesday before election day, the nation would be better able to assess the merits of each party's programme, and what is even more important, would be less likely to be stampeded by false and fictitious claims and by dangerous and unsubstantiated charges, the ''Zinoviev'' letter episode and the ''Reichstag'' fire incident must not find their counterparts in Australian radio transmission.'
(Paragraph 268)

It is worth pointing out that radio and television were most definitely not used in association with the Zinoviev letter in Britain in 1925, the incident that Arthur Calwell in 1969 used as his major reason for not trusting commercial radio, for the obvious fact that the BBC had not commenced its regular broadcasting services at that time and, in fact, did not commence until 1927.
In its report in 1954, the Royal Commission on Television recommended that the blackout should apply to television and radio equally:

'The provision of section 89 (2) of the Broadcasting Act 1942-1953 which provides that no political matter shall be broadcast on the two days preceding . . . should be applied to the televising of political matter on both the national and the commercial television services.'
(Paragraph 466-Recommendation 57)

The only modifications to the original provision were made in 1969 by an amendment through the inclusion of sub-section 116 (4A) which allows the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to exempt from the blackout provision, particular stations during by-elections for the House of Representatives and State elections. Before 1969, even a by-election for one seat meant a nation- wide blanket application of the blackout.

Since the provision was introduced into the legislation in 1942, there have been several occasions, usually during an election lead-up, when politicians have defended the ban. Their argument has been based invariably on one of the following premises:
It inhibits the possibility of last-minute deception.
It provides respite from political pressure.
It reflects the Commonwealth Government's power to control one element of the media.

The possibility of last-minute deception is not lessened by the blackout, it is merely moved forward a few days. In addition the reverse is the case. If a newspaper makes a statement on polling day then, at present, there is no way of gaining redress. However, if the electronic media were in operation then the likely situation would be that a right of reply would be granted and, at least, some ground could be made up by the offended party.
The argument about breathing spaces is a thoroughly paternalistic one. As Donald Horne has put it:
'The whole idea of breathing spaces, peace and calm, and quiet study of candidates' records is so artificial that it is laughable . . .'

One might say generally that political activity feeds on discussion and the energetic presentation of issues but it languishes in government-enforced ' breathing spaces'. A society in which elections went 'calmly and quietly' would almost certainly not be a democratic one. Calm and quiet are usually enforced from above . . .'
Senator Chipp on 11th October 1980 put the point about discrimination against one media source in this way:

'If we are genuinely committed to freedom of speech, there is no excuse for this continued political censorship of radio and television before an election. It is blatant discrimination to allow the Press to report on election issues at this time, yet impose a blackout on radio and television.
If people do not want to read about the election they can skip stories in their newspapers, or not buy a newspaper at all. People should be given the same freedom of choice on radio and television.
If they did not want to listen to or view election material, they could change to another station or switch off'.
Radio and television may be more intrusive than newspapers, but I question whether the difference is of sufficient significance as to warrant a curtailment of freedom of speech.

As Senator Chipp has said, everybody is free to turn off electoral broadcasts- indeed, anyone who wishes to impose a personal or domestic pre-election blackout is free so to do with only minor disruptions to listening and viewing habits.

Even with the broadcasting blackout, those who object to electoral material close to polling day will still be bombarded by newspapers, posters, bumper stickers, slogan buttons. T-shirts, graffiti and other eye-catching material. Their homes will still be invaded by loud-hailers in the hands of party supporters cruising through the suburbs thundering out electoral messages.
Opposition to the ban has come from many organisations and individuals. In 1969 , for example, Mr Peacock, speaking on the broadcasting and television bill, said:

''I therefore put it to the Minister than the ban on the broadcasting of election matter during the 3 days prior to the close of the poll is outmoded. During this period we can read in our daily newspapers all that pertains to the electoral battle that is going on. Although the current news on the election, which is of utmost importance to the nation, is fully reported in the newspapers , it cannot be reported by the television or radio stations from the Wednesday night prior to the poll on Saturday. Frankly, I believe that this legislation belongs to a bygone era. I think it is a negation of the principle that news should be unfettered.

As the Minister is aware, the broadcasting ban applies to both Federal and State elections. Under the Broadcasting and Television Act-the Act which will be amended by the Bill that the House is now debating-all television and radio stations are prohibited from broadcasting any election matter from the Thursday morning up to the close of the poll on the Saturday. I make a strong statement whan I say that I think it is an absurd piece of legislation which debars television and radio stations from fulfilling their role of bringing current news and information on all major issues of the day to the public. I urge the Minister to consider whether the Act can be amendmend in this regard before the next Federal election.''

The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in its report '' 'Self-regulation for Broadcasters'-a report on the Public inquiry into the concept of self-regulation for Australian Broadcasters-Australian Broadcasting tribunal, AGPS, Canberra, 1977'', when considering evidence which had been given regarding section 166 (4) , made the following comment:

''The Tribunal finds it difficult to disagree with the bulk of the witnesses, particularly as the provision is not consistent with the practice of most other Western countries. The embargo was originally introduced to restrict the transmission of last-minute, alarmist material in election campaigns. There is, however, nothing to prevent newspapers from presenting such material and we believe it inequitable to discriminate between media.''
The Postal and Telecommunications Department in its report-''Australian Broadcasting'' recommended:

''It is proposed that the 'election period' be defined as the period commencing on the day of issue of the writ or writs for an election and ending at midnight on the day preceding the day of the poll, thereby limiting the 'blackout' period to those hours between midnight and the close of the poll.''

The Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, in 1977 felt that the electronic blackout was a bit antiquated and promised to review the ban after the election, as did the A.L .P. according to a report in 'The Age' of 7th December of that year.

In 1978 Mr Tony Staley, the Minister for Post and Telecommunications, told the Melbourne Press Club that he hoped to end the ban on the broadcasting of political news and commentary. The ban, he said, was ''absurd and odd''. That ban is still absurd and odd but it has not been repealed.

The A.J.A. has constantly opposed the provisions of the Broadcasting Act which allow this censorship and made the point in October 1980 that it was disturbed that politicians give only lip service to suggestions that the offending section be removed.

Derryn Hinch has, over the years, waged his own personal battle to have the ban lifted and has been joined by the Federation of Radio Broadcasters. Their report ''A Proposal To End The Election 'Blackout' '', while endorsing a lesser proposal still advocates the abolition of the blackout in its entirety-as does the Public Broadcasting Association of Australia, the Australian Newspapers Council and the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations.
The absurdities of the ban are apparent at every Federal election or by- election. A few examples must suffice.

In October 1980, the afternoon host of Sydney radio station 2GB, thought she was on safe ground if she put to air an incisive piece on the summer cockroach plague. An alderman of the Sydney City Council's community services and health committee was interviewed. He claimed to have been bitten by a cockroach, but made the fatal mistake of saying that cockroaches were the number one enemy of the ALP City Council.
The programme's producers feared mere mention of the ALP would be in contravention of the Broadcasting and Television Act. The cockroach story was put off until after the election.

In April 1981 ABC national news bulletins, which emanate from Sydney were prohibited from making any reference to a row in Parliament between Mr Fraser and Mr Hayden over the Rundle shale oil issue. This was because of the by- election for the NSW seat of Wentworth. Listeners were duly informed that they were hearing restricted bulletins. Victorians were able to hear a report of the Rundle row in the Victorian edition immediately following the national news.

What makes the whole thing farcical is that the ABC is obliged to broadcast Parliament, so listeners throughout Australia, including NSW, were able to hear the entire debate between Mr Hayden and Mr Fraser when it took place.

There is even a Q.C.'s advice that if, for argument's sake, the wife of the Prime Minister or the Leader of the Opposition were at a flower show and fell from the podium and sprained her ankle, a television or radio station that broadcast the information would be liable to prosecution.

This Bill seeks to remove a perversion of freedom of the Press and the public's right to know; it seeks to avoid the situation whereby radio and television have to go through the absurd charade of pretending politics do not exist during the last 72 hours of each election campaign; it seeks to avoid the situation whereby a radio broadcaster can be acting against the law by merely reading from a newspaper story about a current election campaign. It takes the commonsense stance that if it is good enough for a newspaper to report on political events during the last day of a campaign then it is good enough for a radio or television station to do the same.

The pre-election blackout on radio and TV commentary is neither reasonable nor logical. There is no rational argument as to why the electronic media should be muzzled. The community is entitled to receive comment and information on all issues affecting their vote on all available media services.

It is not 1942. It is 1982-forty years on, we live in a society in which an ever-increasing number of people rely on the electronic media to receive news and background information. The electronic newspaper is now in Australia and yet we have a law which says that if it is printed on paper it is legal but if it is printed on paper and shown on a screen it is illegal. What is the situation if instead of the electronic newspaper being broadcast it is relayed through cable into homes and offices?

While most parliamentarians come from the cities of this country, I would remind all senators that there are still many towns and settlements in this country which do not receive their daily newspaper for some days after it is printed. In this case to blackout their main means of information, namely radio and television, is to put them at a serious disadvantage.

In a pre-election situation electronic media is able to offer more immediate means for community feedback and consultation and an effective means for the correction of any untrue or mistaken statement.

The election blackout must be removed. It is a democratic right for all Australian citizens to have access to all information from all sources. It is time this absurd and regressive ban was removed. This Bill will dispose of it in its entirety.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Durack) adjourned.

—It has not yet been supplied to me. I consider it, in fact, a gross discourtesy.
—It hasn't been supplied to me either.

—Well, it has been supplied to other people and other parties who are concerned directly with industrial relations. I wonder whether it is not , in fact, a deliberate attempt to deprive me and the Democrats of information necessary to make a fully informed comment.

SPEECH.PARA: The statement by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) on behalf of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) identifies four factors affecting industrial relations in this country. The first factor is the structure of Australian unions and their heavy dependence on craft unions rather than industry or even enterprise unions. The second is a breakdown of any sense of commitment to bargains made and the spirit and intent of conciliation and arbitration processes. Thirdly is the constant resort to indiscriminate use of union power, often before the parties have reached the bargaining table, as a first rather than a last resort. Fourthly is the Federal-State division of industrial powers. A cynic might add that the Government is also a major problem in industrial relations at present. There were four major whinges but the Government has tackled only one in any concrete sense, that is, the structure of Australian unions.

The Government, having suffered the embarrassment of being forced to negotiate its own legislation last year when Senator Button introduced a Bill to encourage the amalgamation of unions, now says that it will encourage the creation of industry unions. It is difficult to see how this can be done except by union amalgamation. In fact, this was what Senator Button's attempt encouraged last year. We believe that union amalgamation is a worthy aim. As I have said several times since entering this Senate, Australia has far too many unions-about 11 times as many as, for example, West Germany. Union amalgamation, therefore, is to be welcomed, especially on an industry basis.

The mention which is made in the Government's report on enterprise unions, however, disturbs me greatly as it had disturbed the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Apparently the Government intends to allow employees of any enterprise or company with more than 100 employees to form a union. I can only say that this would be sheer madness. The number of individual unions would mushroom ten- fold. I ask the Minister to clarify the Government's position on this point as a matter of some urgency.

The Government appears to be doing something positive on one front and, at the same time, something negative-taking a step backwards-on another front. Let us talk about the other three fronts that the Government has raised in its statement. Unions and employers will not regain magically a sense of commitment to bargains made in the spirit and intent of conciliation and arbitration processes simply because the Government asks them to do so, even if the Government asks very nicely. It is naive to expect that to happen. Instead we believe that the Government should introduce a legislative framework for direct bargaining and binding contracts between unions and employers. Such legislation need not necessarily be modelled on the American system but it must recognise the value of Australian traditions and institutions. This would surely be a more effective measure than simply asking the employers and unions to be good people.

One of the saddest things in Australia's industrial life is the gulf between labour, organised or not organised, and capital. It is a division which has existed in our society-as in many others-for centuries. I believe passionately that the way to industrial harmony is through industrial democracy. Such brilliant and compassionate men as Carl Zeiss, Fletcher Jones and many others have shown that is can work. The Bill which passed this Senate in the last days of 1981 was a start. I fervently hope that eventually it will become law. If the interests of workers and capital become more closely identified each has more to gain through improved industrial relations. Unions are suspicious of things such as profit sharing and employee share ownership. They are suspicious that these are just one-way streets and that labour gives away more than the employers. But this has been demonstrated to be not the case in Germany, Scandanavia and Japan. Employees can do just as well and may be in a position to gain more from the introduction and practice of the principles of industrial democracy. It is the experience of these countries with industrial democracy that it greatly reduces industrial disputation.

Lastly, Mr Viner said that employers have complained of the Federal-State division of industrial relations powers. Of course, our complex political and legal system is a heavy millstone around the neck of industrial relations whichever way we go, as it is in many other fields. But successive administrations have shown little inclination to do anything about this. The expense of having seven separate wages tribunals is immense, yet Australians appear to accept this mad hatter's tea party with the resigned air of people unable to shape their own destiny.

Surely the first priority in industrial relations has to be to repeal the present Conciliation and Arbitration Act and to replace it with modern legislation which reflects today's attitudes and needs. The present Act is one of the most complex in the land and it is 80 years old. It is a major impediment to progressive industrial relations in this country. Why should the Act be changed? The most important decision which has to be made is the kind of wages and conditions fixing system that we want. Traditionally Australia has had a central wage fixing authority-the Commission itself. However, the Commission has not been alone in this central wage fixing approach. Australia is bedevilled also by six State wage body industry groups and over-award payments in negotiations on a company by company basis.

The Australian Democrats propose a major simplification of this hugely expensive and ineffective system, based on the abolition of the negotiating role of industry associations and State wages authorities and a major role change for the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. We believe that the Commission should set minimum wages and conditions and monitor adherence to agreements, but that over-award wages and conditions ought to be negotiated on a company by company basis with agreements codified in written, binding contracts. I stress the words 'a company by company basis' or 'an enterprise by enterprise basis'. Those two words are synonymous. Surely companies are the best judges of what they can afford and the productivity improvements that they can achieve-not industry associations or distant wages tribunals. Surely local union officials are the best judges of when to press and when to back off in negotiating contracts. Both sides, on a company to company basis, would have access to all the resources under the command of the industrial unions. That is the first priority-a basic change in the law under which our conciliation and arbitration procedures operate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You would not impose that on the States, would you?

—I believe that the chaos in industrial relations is such that a constructive approach to a revision of our Conciliation and Arbitration Act would be welcomed by the States. The fact that we have had wage indexation for three years proves that the States are prepared to co-operate with the Commonwealth in the wage fixing area. Indexation was not possible without State co-operation. I believe State co-operation would be forthcoming in a basic revision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. There is no other way. The Act has to be revised.

SPEECH.PARA: The second priority is the creation of a climate in which the traditional labour versus capital conflict can be dissolved. That is the essential thrust of the Industrial Democracy Bill. The Australian Democrats were very proud to have it passed in the Senate in November. That Bill was-and this speaks volumes for industrial relations in Australia-the first such Bill ever to be introduced into the Australian Parliament. The Bill seeks to encourage, by means of a reduction in company tax, the creation of works councils, profit centre groups, profit sharing and employee share ownership. The Australian Democrats believe in the rapid development of manufacturing industry on the sure and firm foundation of a partnership between capital and labour and not on confrontation. Our long term aim is development of this concept to the point where 50 per cent of the shares of companies are owned by employees-in other words, a partnership between capital and labour. Employee share ownership has been praised by the Chairman of the Sydney Stock Exchange, Mr Frank Mullens. It is also, I understand, the platform of the Liberal Party, although not much has been done to encourage it during the lifetime of this Parliament. Enlightened industrial relations policies are undoubtedly the key to the success of industry in Germany and Japan . English speaking countries keep their heads in the sand and they will do so at their own peril.

The Government can play a decisive role in industrial relations by skilful blending of legislation, leadership and education in this area. Australia has industrial chaos because the Government cannot make up its mind whether to adopt a centralised or decentralised wage fixing approach. These two approaches are basically in conflict but yet at present we have both. Fewer unions or company unions are two approaches that are basically in conflict. The Government has not yet resolved that conflict. A central wage fixing system can only work if the unions are prepared to stop their direct bargaining with companies on over-award payments and rely on the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I believe it is unrealistic to expect the unions to do that. The only practical approach is to move to decentralised direct bargaining, tailored to meet the Australian tradition, the Australian character and Australian aims.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate somewhat amazed at the infantile concept of the habits of the Australian work force as set out in this document. It could be said at the outset that this is a sort of political St Paul document, the message ahead of the ultimate legislation. That may be good because perhaps even at this late stage Mr Viner, the Minister for Industrial Relations, will realise what a narrow, transparent document it is. I say that because an assessment of the Australian work force, irrespective of the industry, over the last five years, taking into account the impact of the inevitable technological changes, reveals that the average rank and file trade unionist has a fear of uncertainty. Quite a number of recent disputes have arisen over the question of relativity. People have said: 'What's the difference ? It's only a matter of a few dollars in different classifications?' Other people realise that often it is a question of promotion or progression.

SPEECH.PARA: I will give honourable senators a classic illustration. Let us take the case of the recent New South Wales State railway dispute. It is very nice to have across -the-board broadband agreements when X dollars are paid on an industrial basis. But in many services and public utilities the main inducement is a little difference in the various grades. I think this is manifest in the New South Wales railways where within five years a membership of 20,000 will be compressed to about 13,000. In the traffic grades it is doubtful whether, in the light of certain technological changes, there will be speed of progression for people going, for example, from station assistant to shunter to signal man with all the various relativities. I have in mind the computerisation of the signal system virtually from Newcastle to the Queensland border. The example I have given of the railway system could be perpetuated in so many other areas.

Let me turn to this weird idea of plant unions, for want of a better name. Has the Government looked at the container industry at the moment? It could be said, I think undeniably, that some mergers of the Federated Storemen and Packers Union of Australia, the Federated Clerks Union of Australia and the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia would be advantageous. But if we take the Viner concept of these plant organisations, in Sydney at present there is one container terminal where there will be redundancies. If there is to be a narrow concept, a cocoon as it were, of one terminal, how will rapport be reached with another section of those particular classifications? How are all those classifications absorbed? In contrast, the amalgamation of the three unions concerned in the container industry, or even two of them, would be advantageous. I make that point because the average rank and file member in an industry asks himself at 25 years of age: 'Where will I be when I am 50?'

I think this problem is epitomised at the other end of the scale in small industries involving, for example, the confectionary union. Recently Rowntrees, a chocolate manufacturer, was absorbed by another company. A person over 55 may get, and does get in most instances, a fairly generous severance pay. But what happens to the others? I raised this matter with the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, Mr Neil Brown, during the Rowntree windup. The people over 55-the union of course agreed to this-got, in a sense, a modified golden handshake. But what happened to those people between 25 and 40? The company vaguely said: 'Well , the Commonwealth Employment Office will place them'. When we get this drivel from the Government in this statement, it makes me wonder whether it ever realises the difficulties caused by redundancies and how people are placed.

I sat with Barney French of the Federated Rubber and Allied Workers Union of Australia in negotiations for the workers in the phase-out of the Dunlop company . Dunlop consolidated its industry in Victoria, and I do not object to union consolidation. I can remember meeting the then Minister for Productivity, the present Minister for Immigration and Ethnic affairs, Mr Macphee, with a delegation from the union. To the Minister's credit, negotiations were opened up with Goodyear regarding that company absorbing Dunlop's tyre builders and kindred grades. The other employer said: 'Oh well, of course that is a noisy industry and some of those men have hearing problems. How will we know in X number of years when these men claim industrial deafness that they did not have these hearing problems before? Should I absorb the lot of them?' In this case, with a little bit of give and take, effective redundancy absorption occurred. But in respect of the instances which I have given there have been no utterances from the Government. The Government has the Industrial Relations Bureau. Does it ever realise the human element involved in industrial relations? People who are made redundant are not just a group of statistics.

Without even getting into the field of collective bargaining, I emphasise again that, if the Government wants this minute fragmentation into plant and company unions, it should look, as it does not appear to have done, at the history of United States trade unions and at some of the bloody battles that took place even in the era when President Roosevelt tried to bring civilisation to American trade union relations. There has never been in Australia any of the violence on the shopfloor or outside that was experienced in the United States. The closest I can get to it is the ill-fated dispute on the Kalgoorlie goldfields in 1934 when the mining companies created racialism between the various groups. Besides that, it is very hard to think of any other instances. One thinks of Rothbury, but they are very few and far between. If we get unions into these narrow confines, I do not believe that any of the Australian employers that Mr Viner claims are applauding his scheme will give people permanent employment. Pigs might fly! The smaller a union, the more inclined the employers will be to say: 'You are a good and faithful servant. We cannot do anything for you. Report to the Commonwealth Employment Office'. Once we get this fragmentation, we will get complete chaos.

I will take it a little further. Senator McIntosh is a long-standing and experienced member of a major trade union in the metal industry. He would know, and we know, that with the best of intentions the Government says to the unions: 'Do not be Luddites. Do not resist change'. Does the Government not realise that throughout the open-cut coal fields in Australia of recent times the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association of Australasia has been operating the machinery and the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union has been providing the maintenance, whereas in the underground mines the miners' federation has been the major and dominant group? It is inevitable that there will be honest differences and disputations, but it is wrong to say, whenever there is a strike, that the Australian Labor Party inspired it. I am sorry that the wife of the Queensland Premier is not present in the chamber. The Country Party in Queensland inspired the miners' federation in the taxation brawl it had with the Treasurer John Howard with respect to taxation of certain allowances for habitation in distant places. Of course, because it suited the Country Party it cheered on the miners' federation in that instance, but in New South Wales it is said to be anarchist and in Western Australia, I suppose, it would be said to be the same. This shows the Government's inconsistency and hypocrisy.

A Country Party member of the Queensland State Government, whose nickname I was told by former Senator McAuliffe is Pinkie Lester, is an avid organiser for the union, and what he said about John Howard left anything that we said about him in the other place very poor in comparison. I make that indictment of the Country Party. When it suited it for an electoral advantage it tried to become super-militant. It says something for it as a union bargainer that I do not think John Howard has yet done anything about taxing the rental allowance of miners and other people who work in distant areas. That shows how much hypocrisy has been produced.

I go to another example. Mr Deputy President, you would have noticed the incessant dialogue I have had with the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). I have said: 'The Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia is endeavouring to go into the resources field in Western Australia, but we have a State arbitration set-up and a Federal one. What are you doing to anticipate to some extent the collisions that will arise?' All I have got from Senator Durack, who is a very polite and pleasant Minister, is: 'Well, it is a deep question. We have to keep talking'. What I want to know is when Sir John Moore and his counterpart in Western Australia will come up with a formula to anticipate a little of the give and take that will unquestionably arise when some unions from the east seek to go into Western Australia. I am not attempting to provide a formula now, but I believe we should be ready for it. Instead of putting out 12 roneoed sheets of half-baked ideas, it would be much better if Mr Viner said: 'Sir John Moore has spoken to the presidents of all the State industrial commissions. This is the formula we have for the new deployment of trade unions'. That has not been done and that is the alarming indictment I make at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that the sightboard has been adjusted I can continue with my speech. Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was attempting to analyse the statement of the Minister for Industrial Relations. I made the point that in formulating any proper industrial policy one has to analyse the motivations of the Australian work force. I repeat-I have said this on at least five occasions when we have dealt with this type of legislation-that since well over five years ago when the full thrust of the technological revolution hit Australia there has been no forward planning from the Government down. Originally this was so in relation to the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association and has remained the situation in relation to all the subsequent adjustments that occurred. If I were looking for a key word in relation to current wage agreements it would be 'relativity'. It may be that in some selected areas a person maintains his industrial status regardless of what industry he goes to, but in so many areas it is a matter of progressing from a lower grade to the ultimate in perhaps 10 years time. That is why unions are rightly so jealous of maintaining that relativity.

SPEECH.PARA: It might be argued that before we departed from the two tier wage system in which the fitter was the benchmark for the purpose of making adjustments-we had the base rate and a margin for skill-it was much easier to assess wage trends. Of course, the Government has never been prepared to recognise public utilities and public services generally; it has always put the glamour industries first with the others trailing behind. Let us take the recent transport situation. I refer to the railway industry. There is no question in my mind that if greater recognition had been given to various grades and their relationships with one another the parties involved would not have become locked in. The Minister's statement is lacking in certain respects. There are obviously constant collisions. I refer to the conflict between State and Federal awards. It was only when serious problems arose at Kernell that some attempts were made by the Industrial Commission of New South Wales and its Federal counterpart under Sir John Moore to devise a formula.

As I said in dialogue with Senator McIntosh before dinner, we are facing a similar situation in Western Australia. I do not concur completely with the Government about the ambit of the resources boom but we know that as unions from the eastern States seek certain coverage it is inevitable that there will be some disputation. I have had very little response from the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, as to how far we have gone with summit talks on these matters. The problem is not insoluble. This problem looms large each year in the report of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Last night Senator Scott dealt fleetingly with it but the Minister said very little about it.

I come to the point about fragmentation of trade unions. The containerisation industry is probably crying out for mergers. I have in mind the situation concerning the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia, the Federated Storemen and Packers Union of Australia and the Federated Clerks Union of Australia. Let us take Mr Viner's suggestion that small is best. What would be the situation in the container industry in this regard? I know that in the port of Sydney there would be 78 redundancies in one container depot. If we had this minute union component that the Minister talks about there would be no way of siphoning off those people to other depots. In contrast, if we implemented the merger that I suggest, the last-on-first-to-go syndrome would apply. I know that the question of suitability is also a factor, but by and large that principle works best.

I noticed that on page 14 of his circulated statement the Minister referred to the Printing and Kindred Industries Union and the 35-hour working week that was negotiated to apply from December 1982. It always amazes me that whoever prepares these speeches for Mr Viner does not realise that the 40-hour working week came in in 1947. At every trade fair that has been held since, in every trade journal that has been published since and at any inspection of any workshop or plant by a Senate committee that has taken place since, a particular piece of equipment or labour saving device that was not available five years ago is proudly pointed to. I simply say this: Government members who espouse the virtues of the private enterprise system may think that, after all the industrial innovations since 1947, we should simply say to the Printing and Kindred Industries Union: 'You cannot have your shorter working week; it is an indictment on technological change'. The Government has gloated about this matter. I have heard Ministers talking about certain friction between the Australian Journalists Association and the PKIU. That problem has been resolved to a large degree. Obviously with the intense technological development in that area the shorter working week is a reasonable flow on. Both the previous Australian Council of Trade Unions chieftain, Bob Hawke, and his successor, Cliff Dolan, have made it abundantly clear that the question of shorter working hours and technological changes depends specifically on the trade unions involved.

I wish to deal with two other points because they are related to the national wage case. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has been quoted as saying: ' Well, of course, we as a government have certain limits. We can make submissions only indirectly'. But he is remarkably quiet about two points. At least three years ago when the National Labour Advisory Council met the idea was put that we should look at the situation in Western Europe. I refer to the German and French trade unions and, to a lesser degree, the Scandinavians and the effects of stabilised health schemes. The Government has always argued in terms of the number of days lost. I made it abundantly clear to the Government in relation to the duration of strikes that some of the metal trade unions in the United States have been out on strike for eight or nine months and that in the maritime industry one West Coast dispute went on for seven months. That took place under the leadership of Harry Bridges, whom the Government always tries to tell us we should emulate. There is no use in our going overseas to look at precedents.

The point I wish to make is that in stabilising the wage system the Government refuses to face up to two things. When the Labour Advisory Council met three years ago the idea was put that, just as in Western Europe, the role of the Government and the trade unions was to provide stable hospital and medical coverage. Whatever the Government argues about its loyalty to private hospital funds, the simple egalitarian concept is that medical benefit contributions be part of a person's taxable income which he or she pays once a year. Under that concept a person is not subject to the fluctuations every quarter in the premium of the private hospital fund. That is the first point. Secondly, at least when it comes to settling once a year, the process worker does not pay as much for his hospital and medical coverage as does the production manager. The Government should have been prepared to go to the ACTU and to say: 'We will give you this universal coverage. We will expand the Medibank concept. That will virtually roll all the private funds. If people want to have parallel coverage they can do so but the basic rates will be stable'. Nobody says that any health coverage system is free but there should be an equitable system meshed in with the wage system. Unquestionably, people in the trade union movement such as Cliff Dolan would endorse those remarks. This matter was discussed in early exploratory talks that were held but the Prime Minister backed off. I have no doubt that the stabilisation of such a vital cost factor in the economy would have been a bargaining point.

Again, I refer to the European model. It has never been infra dig for European governments to subsidise a basic commodity, whether it be potatoes or meat. During the latter stages of the Chifley Government and at the end of wartime controls subsidies were hard to apply. Economics can be simplified for the trade union movement and the people at large to understand if there is a component in the Budget of x million dollars to keep such things as meat and potatoes accessible to people. That is a good selling point if a government wants a controlled economy. This Government has always backed away from this point. Some of the drivel contained in this statement indicates that the Government will say to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission that there have been sizable changes in margins and, therefore, it cannot adopt a general wage. The Government cannot go to the ACTU or to the people at large and argue as we have argued at times about whether private enterprise has been a little greedy in claiming depreciation of plant or whether it has always done the right thing. In the final analysis, the wage earner who has no other income has very little flexibility when he gets his assessment notice at the end of June. We all know that some people have to pay a little more than they anticipated. They can negotiate to pay by instalments within a certain range. But people who have income from other sources-I was about to call them the buccaneers of commerce, but I may transgress and, in deference to you, Mr Deputy President, I will change that term-have a greater manoeuvrability to stall or delay concerning their taxation obligations.

If the Prime Minister wants industrial peace he can do a number of things. Firstly, by having a more developed computerisation of our manpower statistics, he would be able to foreshadow industrial demands. Secondly, a more across the board effective redundancy scheme should be implemented. Another factor is wage relativity. It is no use harping and badgering the trade union movement. Many of its militants today, such as the air traffic controllers-I assure honourable senators that they are not affiliated with my party although some individuals might vote for the Labor Party and it is their right to be swinging voters- cannot be saddled as being puppets on a string, run by the Labor Party. I assure the honourabe senator from Queensland who is sitting on my left that, although she was not in the chamber when I spoke before the suspension of the sitting, I asked:' Who are the militants'. Let us take the role of the National Country Party in the federal electorate of Dawson when the miners had a problem with John Howard about whether they should pay tax on certain rent concessions for working in distant places. Pinkie Lester, who was more militant than anyone else , was a member of the Country Party. The honourable senator is nodding her head so I accept that she agrees that there are justifiable stoppages and strikes. The honourable senator is now in a dither. Pinkie Lester said there were and he has not divorced himself from that situation.

We hear a lot of drivel about which group is more holy than the other in regard to industrial relations. It comes back to a theme I have often talked about. In a better educated society Jack is as good as his master. I do not care how eloquent a trade union leader is. There is a tendency-I suppose it is good in a democratic society-when a union has put in a submission for someone to ask: ' What about Clause C? Does it mean this?'. The union secretary will say: 'I think it does'. Someone else at the back of the hall will get up and say: 'I move that you come back in a couple of days and tell us just what it means'. We all know the art of negotiation. I would not expect a union secretary to go to the first meeting and to say: 'This is what we meant' because he would not have got that undertaking from the employer. We talk a lot about collective bargaining. There should be a bit of give and take. Honourable senators may imagine that if there is a stoppage on one day the union, the judge and the employer will get together and the union will go back to its members the next day and say that everything is apples. It does not work that way. Five honourable senators could sit outside and have a cup of coffee together. We all regard ourselves as reasonable people. But if honourable senators opposite think that we could reach a settlement in an hour's time, I can assure them that it does not work that way. If it does not work in a small dimension how do people expect it to work on a broad industry basis. There is no way that it will.

I conclude by saying that the duration of stoppages in this country has never been comparable with those in some other countries, notably that of the longshoremen in the United States of America and one or two other areas. This document has supposedly been produced by a sort of modern day political St Paul. It is the message before we get the legislation. Opposition senators, such as my leader, Senator Button, have shown wisdom in dealing with this matter. The problem should be taken in a proper way, firstly, by accepting intelligent mergers of trade unions in given areas with a minimum of delay. Decisions should be reached by the rank and file members. Secondly, the Government should take a good hard look at future basic wage assessments, consider some way of including health coverage as a component and not ignore food subsidies. If it does so it will get a better response from the trade union movement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a ministerial statement on wage determination and industrial relations put down in the Senate by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), representing the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner). Yesterday, I picked up a copy of that day's edition of the Daily Commercial News and Shipping List. This paper contains a four-page supplement giving the current and pending strike status in Australia and overseas countries. Three of the four pages cover Australia. Thirty-four current disputes and 44 pending disputes in Australia are listed. Is it any wonder that, as the Minister said in the statement, the simple truth is that the people of Australia are fed up with strikes? 'Enough is enough' are the words the Minister used. I repeat and confirm them.

SPEECH.PARA: Figures for the days lost in the September 1981 quarter have recently been released. They show that 1,147,000 working days were lost in Australia during that period. Industrial disputes in the sea transport industry cost Australia an average of almost $1.5m per day for each day of 1981. That means that over $500m -half a billion dollars-were lost in one industry in one year in this nation. That represents over $35 for every man, woman and child in Australia. The year 1981 concluded without one single day being completed which was free of disputes affecting at least one sector of shipping. One strike, the flags of convenience bans by maritime unions, resulted in the loss of 2000 ship days at a cost of $ 25m and delays of as long as four months for ships trying to load at Newcastle and Port Kembla.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is Neville Wran's navy-the ships off Newcastle and Sydney.

—The ships off Newcastle and Port Kembla are Neville Wran's navy. Thirty-odd ships are anchored off the New South Wales coast almost permanently. Yesterday there was a report that over 50 ships were anchored off the coast, being kept waiting by the maritime unions. Not only are they losing time but also we are losing our coal export markets because confidence in Australia, as a dependable supplier, has been severely shaken. During this period costs to Australian shipping operators have significantly increased by contributions to insure against strikes. It has almost reached the stage where the club of insurers is refusing to insure Australian shippers. Until January 1982 Australian operators were paying more than double the average premium. In January 1982 new increased premiums were imposed which will again substantially increase the burden which these shippers have to pay. I know that honourable senators opposite tend to think that this is just a matter of some company paying a fee and it does not concern them at all. But the ultimate result is that Australians have to pay the cost.
