Whether importers or exporters pay the burden in the first instance, ultimately every Australian, every man, woman and child in this nation, bears this cost. One shipping company has just given Australia away and withdrawn its services from the Australian trade so we have even less competition in that industry.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite remarkable that the Australian Labor Party leaders have remained strangely silent about these disputes. Apparently they are quite content to allow our private enterprise in Australia to be slowly strangled by these activities. The Wran Government in New South Wales has even entered into sweetheart deals with some unions in the power industry, thus reducing the hours worked from 37 to 35, well knowing that the consequences would be flow-on demands in private enterprise. Yet despite giving in to union demands, what has happened in New South Wales? There is turmoil in the very industries in which the Government entered into arrangements with the unions. The transport, oil and power industries in New South Wales are in absolute chaos and the reason is very simple.

Mr Wran has now finally lashed out. We all know what the reason is. It is the extremists within the union movement and the extremists within the Australian Labour Party, the left-wingers in the organisation, who have created these problems for Mr Wran and the people of Australia. They have created problems wherever the ALP manages to get into government. They create problems for the ALP and for the nation. Now Mr Wran has finally agreed to lash out. I do not know why he lashed out at this late stage. Perhaps it is because the New South Wales State election is over. But whatever the reason his attack is long overdue . No one would disagree with his statements about the lunacy and bloody- mindedness of some union leaders, or his statement that 'union leaders do not give two hoots for the public or for their fellow workers'. He is right in saying that some elements of the union movement seem determined to kill the goose that laid the golden egg-in other words, to kill his Labor Government.

New South Wales, under Labor, has become the strike capital of Australia. In the June quarter of 1981, 53 per cent of the industrial disputes in Australia were in New South Wales. In February 1981 over two-thirds of the working days lost in Australia were in New South Wales. In the first 10 months of 1981 44 per cent of working days lost in Australia were lost due to strikes and industrial stoppages in New South Wales. Over the same period that is almost two-thirds more than in Victoria. Mr Wran's performance is in marked contrast to that of the current Victorian Premier, Mr Thompson, who has demonstrated his talents with the difficult industrial disputes at Newport and Loy Yang, with great success. He is to be congratulated for his success in resolving those disputes. Of course-

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there an election coming up in Victoria as well as a by- election in New South Wales?

—Senator McLaren asks me whether an election is coming up in Victoria. An election is coming up in Victoria and no doubt the honourable senator believes that Mr John Cain will be elected as premier of Victoria. If that happens let there be not the slightest doubt that his left wing will demonstrate to the people of Victoria how they can squeeze another ALP Government and the nation with strikes. Let us look what happened under a Labor Government in 1974. Under Labor a massive 6.3 million working days were lost in Australia in one year-1974-through strikes. Once again let there not be the slightest doubt-
—Tell us about the New South Wales Liberal Party.

—I am sure Senator Sibraa would agree with me that the reason was that the left wing within his own Party squeezed it and pushed it to a point where an impossible situation was created in this nation. This nation was being bankrupted by his own left wing. Mr Wran has finally given us an outburst but what have we heard from the Federal leaders? What has Mr Hayden or Mr Hawke said about these things? They have remained silent. Telecom Australia and the Australian Postal Commission employees ran a strike in November and December 1975 but not a word was heard from Mr Hayden or Mr Hawke. There were disputes in New South Wales coal and power industries and ongoing waterfront and seamen's disputes but not a word was heard from either of them. Of course Mr Hawke knows all about the problems of the left wing because when he was the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions he failed to implement the ACTU's new rules for control of the union movement. Under the left wing influence Mr Hawke was unable to implement the ACTU's rules. The result under his presidency was chaos. I will compare that with the well organised control of the ACTU when it was under the presidency of Mr Albert Monk.

SPEECH.PARA: The ALP can offer nothing but the same formula that failed in 1974. Few aspects of our national life cause more concern to Australians than the state of our industrial relations. An atmosphere of confrontation which Australia is unable to afford pervades our industrial relations. Constant strikes have brought inconvenience and frustration to our citizens and the loss of wages to workers, whether directly involved or not. The productivity of enterprise has suffered immeasurable damage and Australia's trade and balance of payments have been harmed to a dangerous extent. Even Mr Wran finally acknowledged a tendency on the part of many unions to strike first and talk afterwards. Australia's record is indefensible when our relative prosperity is taken into account.

Despite these massive losses to our productivity throughout the nation, this is still a highly prosperous nation. Let us consider the value and quality of our houses, the furniture in our homes, the television sets, the cars and boats. If honourable senators really want to know how wealthy this country is let them look at the size of the dogs which people keep walking around the streets of our capital cities. It is unbelievable to be confronted with dogs which stand three feet six inches high. Sometimes there is not one but two dogs; that is how wealthy this nation is.

The Minister has produced this paper and in it he has suggested a formula that could significantly improve the basis of our industrial relations. It does not seek unnecessary conflict with the unions but rather industrial peace. The three main ingredients of the proposals are as follows: Firstly, the right of employers to stand down workers who, while not on strike themselves, cannot be usefully employed because of strike action by others, secondly, amendment of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to remove preference to unionists clauses; and thirdly, encouragement of the formation of unions based on industries or enterprise. I understand that the ALP suports the formation of unions based on industries but-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I take a point of order. I draw your attention to Standing Order No. 406 which states that not honourable senator shall read his speech. If Senator Lewis claims that he is not reading his speech , at the end of his remarks I will ask that he table the notes from which he is speaking. Senator LEWIS-I take strong exception to ALP senators standing up in the middle of my speeches and having that nonsense written into Hansard. It is only done for that purpose. If anyone in due course reads Hansard he will say: ' Lewis was reading his speech'. That is absolute nonsense and the honourable senator knows that. I was reading the three main ingredients of the proposals from the Minister's paper. Of course I have them written out in another form but this is what the Minister said his proposals were. That is what I was reading. It is absolute nonsense. The Opposition does it to me all the time. I am sure its purpose is to have something put into Hansard so that someone in due course will say: 'That was a great speech by Lewis but he must have been reading it'.
—And you just admitted you were.
—I was reading a part of the notes relating to what the Minister said as to what were the main ingredients of his proposal.
—Where did you get all the figures on the States when you were accusing Wran?

—Senator McLaren asks me where I got the information from in relation to Mr Wran. If Senator McLaren read one of the answers by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to a question in the House of Representatives this afternoon he would find all that detail and more. I did not want to go any further in relation to the nature of the proposals put forward by the Minister in his speech. I have not yet had the opportunity of examining the detailed legislation. But as a member of the industrial relations back bench committee I shall, in due course, get an opportunity to look at that legislation. I look forward to examining it to see the way in which the Government proposes to implement these proposals. I hope that the legislation leads to the development of better industrial relations between industry and the unions. There is much which needs to be done in this field. I hope that in due course there will be some development of worker participation in industries. I believe that this is the big possibility for the solution to our industrial problems. It may very well be that enterprise-based unions, which the Opposition apparently so strongly opposes, will lead to worker participation in industry. I hope that some decent industrial relations develop as a result of the proposals put forward by the Minister and as a result of other proposals which he indicated in his speech he had in mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard Senator Lewis make an attack on the trade union movement. He said that all industrial disputation in this country was of their making. It is my belief that governments should keep right out of the industrial relations arena. If governments, Federal or State, want to improve industrial relations then I believe that they should vacate this area completely. The Federal Government could play a valuable role in industrial relations by improving trade union training courses and by training the employers of this country in industrial relations. Never in all my life have I seen worse management than exists in Australia. I think there is a lot to be desired in management in this country. I think the Federal Government could play a role in setting up training facilities for improving management.

SPEECH.PARA: A lot has been said about improving industrial relations. It is my firm conviction that industrial relations will improve only when conciliation really means something in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. Many people refer to this Act as the Arbitration Act. They forget that 'Conciliation' comes before ' Arbitration'. Firms that have taken an interest and consulted with the unions at their work place have overcome the problems that exist in industrial relations. Fletcher Jones and Staff Pty Ltd is one of those firms; there are many others. It is because it has not been beyond management's dignity to go on to the shop floor and converse with the workers to find out what their problems were that many of these firms have overcome industrial relations problems.

I believe that collective bargaining is one of the ways forward and should be investigated. I worked in probably the most turbulent of all industries, the waterfront industry. I was one of the people who encouraged the union to go into collective bargaining.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has got worse since you left it.

—It has not got worse. I believe that it was because of mismanagement by management that industrial relations problems escalated. When sensible agreements were worked out in 1967 with the employers, they thought that they would probably do away with the numbers of waterside workers if they allowed them permanency in their jobs. Sensible agreements were made. Unfortunately some people in the employers group thought they could farm work out to people outside the industry. They gave work to the storemen and packers outside that industry. That was the worst thing they could possibly have done. We told them so at the time. Within 12 months they had more industrial disputation outside the waterfront. They would not allow amalgamation with the waterside workers. Today they are looking at that quite differently.

SPEECH.PARA: There should be industry unions. If industry unions are not allowed to be formed we can never have industrial peace. The fact is that employers come to agreements with the major unions and they forget about the little groups of people who belong to the multitude of other unions within the industry. That is their downfall; there is no doubt about that. I was Acting Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation of Port Adelaide. We had come to a sensible agreement. Three people were supplying fuel to the waterfront in that port. Employers would not give them reasonable conditions comparable with those enjoyed by waterside workers in that port. The employers were prepared to close that port rather than give satisfactory conditions to those three people. I went to the employers and virtually told them what to do. People in all parts of an industry should belong to the one union. When collective bargaining is finalised no section of an industry will be forgotten. It is natural that, if a wage rise or better conditions are given to one group of people, turmoil will be created in other sections of that industry. That is what is happening. Many employers are blind to this. I believe there should be better training of employers as managers and for unions. Many unions and many employers have not been educated enough to be able to negotiate. Until the day comes that they are educated we cannot expect better industrial relations.

Industrial relations in this country have been used as a political football. I believe that that is the worst aspect of it. Governments, both State and Federal , have used and encouraged strikes to overcome all sorts of difficulties. They then go to the people and say that the problems are the fault of the workers, the strikers. Not one worker whom I have known over the years has ever wanted to go on strike. He has been forced to go on strike.

The conciliation and arbitration court system is so jammed up that if one makes a claim to the court it is nothing to have to wait for three, four or five years to have it heard. Until one goes on strike one cannot even have a matter heard by a court. That is the truth of the matter. If we have to rely on th arbitration court system I believe we will never have industrial peace. It is up to the trade union movement and the employers. I believe that no attempt should be made to go to an arbitration court.

There should be collective bargaining. People should work out the problems together. Workers should understand the problems of an industry. More information should pass from management to labour. If that happened, there would be less intrigue and there would be more contentment. People who work in an industry and who are prepared to give their life's work to that industry are entitled to some security. They are entitled to know whether that industry will be profitable and whether it is selling its products. Nothing should be hidden from the employees in an industry. There should be a working relationship. There are many ways in which management and labour can and should get together. There is nothing wrong with the Australian worker. I have seen many workers from all over this country. If they have been led by decent, capable men who can deal with workers, industries have progressed. I believe the Australian worker, given a chance, is the best worker in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Second to none anywhere in the world.

—I thank Senator Siddons. I believe Australian workers are the best. This country should not be in these difficulties. This country has 15 million people. The average person in this country is reasonably well educated and healthy. We have huge mineral resources in this country. We can supply all the food we can eat and we export large quantities. If a sincere attempt were made to arrive at better industrial relations they could be achieved, but while industrial relations are used as a political football by trying to implement laws in this place, better industrial relations will never be achieved. There will always be mistrust and anxiety. People involved in collective bargaining do not have a judge to blame. If they accept a bad agreement they can blame only themselves. I believe that is the answer. We should involve people. It is ridiculous; no worker wants to take out of an industry more than it is possible to take out. What is the sense of killing the goose that lays the golden egg?

SPEECH.PARA: As I said before, workers in this country want security and a reasonable return for their labour. Many industrial problems are caused because many matters are hidden within an industry, and that should not be the case. There should be more open negotiation and better forward planning. Information should be given to the workers in an industry. I believe that is the way in which we can overcome the problems. The problems will never be resolved by legislation. A lot of hard work is involved in resolving them. All the claptrap that has been put down in the Parliament is rubbish. The only way in which we can come to some sensible solution is for the Government to put some more money into training unionists and employers. There is no other way. The more people we bring into an industrial dispute the longer that industrial dispute takes to settle. My experience is that the people involved in disputes should keep away from lawyers and governments. The employers and the workers are the only people who should be able to work out those problems. The problem is always made much worse by bringing in a third party. If we refer to the history of the trade union movement we see that when disputing parties kept away from lawyers they were far better off. Governments have no place and no role to play in this situation. The worst thing a government ever did in the waterfront industry was to establish the stevedoring industry authority. That was the biggest thorn in the side of the employers and the workers. I do not believe that the involvement of a third party improves industrial relations one iota.

There is a need to improve industrial relations. The whole of Australia can improve; we can make it a better country. People do not want to go on strike but they are forced to do so because of the system. Many people who have knocked the trade union movement in the past have forgotten what the trade union movement has done in Australia. It has brought about a better and fairer sharing of the wealth of this country. If anyone thinks we can work without a trade union movement, he should look at countries where trade unions are not allowed to operate freely. In those countries 90 per cent of the wealth is owned by 10 per cent of the population. It is a disgrace how dictatorships restrict trade unions . Do we want to happen in this country what is happening today in Poland and other places like that? We hear members of the Government continually knocking the trade union movement. Instead of trying to help overcome problems they are creating problems. The Utah strike in the coal industry was never warranted; that should never have come about. People who work hard in isolated areas should have a tax rebate on their housing. People who work on railway lines in the middle of nowhere and live in terrible conditions should get cheaper rent. Why should they be charged a higher rate of taxation because they get that benefit? That was a ridiculous strike. There was also a strike in Western Australia caused by Court's terrible legislation which provided that if more than three people held a meeting they could be fined. A group of unionists held a meeting in an open paddock. They were not interfering with anyone. The leaders were gaoled. If honourable senators think that that type of attitude will bring about better industrial relations they have another think coming. We can never have peace in those conditions.

Governments should get right out of the industrial relations area and encourage workers and employers to get together to work and to build good products. I believe in people working when they are at the work place. Both employers and unionists can do a job. This country can do much better; there is no doubt about that. Legislation or ministerial statements such as this one will not help at all. I do not believe that this Government has seriously looked at solving the problems. The Government wants to use industrial relations as a political football. That is unfair, unjust and unwarranted. That is not the way in which to solve the problem. There are better ways, and it is about time we started to pursue them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia has often been called the lucky country. Most of us take this assessment as a self-evident truth, although its author actually intended it ironically. If looked at from outside-by Singapore, say, or Japan-we must seem to have everything going for us: Immense natural resources, an homogeneous and well educated population, negligible racial frictions, plenty of space and sunshine, a very strong strategic situation with no discernible threats. What more could any nation want? Yet to those same foreign countries we seem to have a desire to destroy ourselves. Insane industrial disputes seem to be the order of the day: 'A tinge of lunacy', as the New South Wales Labor Premier, Mr Wran, said. Strikes are destroying our reputation overseas as a reliable supplier. Our living conditions suffer through transport strikes, power strikes and mail strikes. The list seems endless. Perhaps the most useful service Telecom Australia could provide would be a dial- a-strike service. Yet to foreigners, and to an increasing number of Australians too, these strikes not only harm an enormous number of people but also they do not do anyone any good.

SPEECH.PARA: Apparent wage gains are soon eaten up by wage induced inflation. Unions try to leap-frog other unions with catch-up claims and the whole business starts again- as if it had ever stopped. More and more Australians are feeling that there must be a better way of getting fair wages and conditions of employment. They feel helpless. Industrial action seems to be above the law, above community interests . Things certainly will not be changed by anti-strike marches, though these are an indication that the public is fed up with strikes, nor will they be changed by tinkering piecemeal with the law, trying to impose a solution. We must solve the problem by reaching a consensus of reasonable people-there are plenty of them- and on the process isolate the totally unreasonable people. There are not as many of those as some people think.

What is wrong with our system of industrial relations? The first and in many ways the most intractable problem is the 'them' and 'us' attitude between labour and management which we have largely inherited from Britain. The idea that the job of the employees is to oppose the management whatever the cost may be was perhaps summed up in a poem by Henry Lawson called 'The Old Unionist' which had the old unionist saying:
I don't know if the cause be wrong,
Or if the cause be right-
I've had my day and sung my song,
And fought the bitter fight.
To tell the truth, I don't know what
The boys are driving at,
But I've been Union twenty years,
And I'm too old to 'rat'.

That irrational attitude is what is doing immense damage to a rational approach to our industrial relations. Somehow-the government must give the lead-we have to break down this 'them' and 'us' confrontational attitude. One way in which this has been exacerbated-I regret to say this particularly as a distinguished lawyer is in the chair of the Senate-is by the excessive legalism of our industrial relations procedure. That too uses the confrontational adversary system of 'them' and 'us' to try to solve industrial problems. That is very damaging in trying to achieve a reasonable consensus. The revolutionary, Jack Cade, who led a revolt in the reign of Henry VI said at the start of his revolution or so Shakespeare had him say: 'The first thing we must do is to kill off all the lawyers'. I think that might be going a little far, nevertheless in the field of industrial relations it would not be a bad start.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those with law degrees.

—Those with law degrees. I think there are some bush lawyers around who would, no doubt, survive. Nevertheless, we have to get away from the excessive legalism of our industrial relations problems. The adversary system which is the basis of British law does immense damage to the sensible resolution of industrial problems.

SPEECH.PARA: The second great problem that we have is in the number of unions. We have at the moment according to the last count-the count is always a little uncertain- 316 unions. This causes damage because there is an endless field of demarcation disputes. We can see this right across the Australian industrial scene-for example, on the waterfront and we have by far the worst waterfront record in the world; over half such disputes in the world occurred in Australia-or even in an activity like building the Omega tower in Victoria. Demarcation disputes are the most intractable problems that we have. But there is even worse than that. Any one of a number of unions which is dissatisfied can go on strike and bring an entire industry to a halt. The other unions involved, which may want no part of this and which may think the union concerned is totally wrong, are powerless to prevent that strike.

Look at this problem. If you want to travel by air any one of 11 unions could stop you-the unions of the airline hostesses, the flight stewards, the airline flight engineers, the air pilots, the transport workers, civil air operations and all the transport workers. If you travel by train any one of 19 unions might stop you. If you want to build a city building one of at least 20 unions could call a halt. If you want to build a ship no less than 10 unions are involved. The situation is absurd. If it did not exist no one would believe that any country would be so mad as to have it. This, of course, has given rise to what the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) has just introduced-a system whereby when one union goes on strike employers can stand down the members of other unions for whom there is no suitable work. That is, I think and I hope, a transition provision until we can arrive at a situation of having industry unions or enterprise unions where that requirement would not exist.

It is obvious that we badly need a single union involved with each enterprise. There are two approaches to this: One is the industry union system which is widely used in West Germany and Sweden and the other is the enterprise union system which is most developed in Japan. There is something to be said for each of them though for the Japanese system to work requires an informal negotiating system which is peculiarly Japanese and which would be hard to transpose into this country. Nor do I think the West German system of industry unions would be immediately adaptable to Australia. For instance, in West Germany there are only 16 unions covering what to us would be an enormous range of activities. Nevertheless, I think we can and should work towards having single unions for each enterprise. These would normally be industry unions but sometimes, where appropriate, we would accept-we must facilitate this-having single enterprise unions. I do not suggest for a moment that enterprise unions would be practical as the general solution to Australia's industrial relations problems.

How will we achieve industry unions? The Australian Council of Trade Unions' policy on this issue is transparently phoney. It says that it is in favour of industry unions achieved through a process of amalgamation. There is no way in which we will achieve industry unions through a process of amalgamation. Many existing unions-the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union is one simple example-extend across a range of industries by any definition. If we want to achieve industry unions we must do it by both amalgamation and by breaking up existing unions so that they can achieve a single union covering that industry. We must agree-I think the Government has to take the lead again in this-on what we are trying to achieve with industry unions and find what industries there are . I think, if we look at it, we will probably find that there are about 60 industries in Australia which would justify having a separate industry union. That must be the subject of discussion and agreement. When we introduce our legislation on amalgamations we must encourage those amalgamations which lead to industry unions and strongly discourage amalgamations that lead away from industry unions. If the ACTU is sincere it will strongly support the Government in that action.

The third great problem area is our wage settling procedure which at the moment is not working. I think most people would agree with that. The arbitration system has largely broken down. We have to look for a new system of wage settling. One solution that we must look at very carefully is enforceable contracts between management and unions in particular enterprises or particular industries where appropriate. At the moment a number of agreements of this nature have been reached but the ordinary common law remedies for breach of contract will not apply because under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act if a dispute occurs it will go to the arbitration system. We need an amendment to the Act to make enforceable contracts between management and labour for a prescribed period effective. That is a system which works reasonably well in America and one which we should look at very carefully in this country.

The fourth great difficulty that we have-it is almost a second feature of the ' them' and 'us' attitude-is the lack of worker involvement in management. To my mind there is no reason in principle why the suppliers of capital should have all the say in what goes on in industry or in enterprise and the providers of labour have none. What we must work towards is a system whereby there is balanced and appropriate representation influenced by both parties-not merely by a strike, no-strike mechanism from labour, but one in which labour can have a sensible input into looking at the way in which that industry can best prosper. During the last parliamentary session Senator Siddons raised a proposal to that end. I did not agree with that proposal, but I agree with his purpose. What we must look at-I believe the Senate is the appropriate place to do it-is how we can work towards that. Again, for that to be achieved will require active government action.

The final area of concern is the very weak position of the ACTU. Its normal reaction when anything happens-let us say a demarcation dispute between two of its member unions-is to wring its hands. What we have to do, somehow, is to give the ACTU more power, by legislation if necessary, but also to make it more responsible to the community, because a weak ACTU is a very bad thing for the community and for the industrial relations in this country.

I have outlined what I believe is wrong and what are the areas of concern in our industrial relations. They will not be solved quickly or easily. Many of them are ingrained into our system and our society. What the Minister has done is to tackle some of these problems. I think it is quite wrong to say that what he has done is confrontational. The people of this country are sick and tired of what is going on in our industrial relations area. They are looking to the Government to give a lead. I suppose one could say that any lead is bound to be confrontational. What we must do though as a government is to give a lead as to what needs to be done. What the Minister has done-I support what he has done-is to indicate that we will introduce the power to stand down employees for whom there is no work when industrial action has stopped the business of an enterprise. We have to understand that these proposals on stand down powers operate only if there is industrial action and employees cannot be usefully employed because of that action. If the unions accept the normal process of negotiation, of conciliation and arbitration, there will be no requirement for stand downs.
I dealt earlier with the question of enterprise-based unions, whether they be industry unions or sole enterprise unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a difference.

—There is a difference. The honourable senator was not here when I was talking about this matter earlier. I mentioned that difference at some length. We must work towards achieving a single union covering an enterprise. It may be an industry union or in certain selected cases it may be an enterprise union. I hope we will get some support from both sides of this chamber for what surely is in the interests of all Australians and, for that matter, all unionists.

SPEECH.PARA: The final point where it is alleged that the Minister has been confrontational is the suggestion that there should be voluntary unionism. I think I should say here that I do not find compulsory unionism abhorrent or wrong, provided the union is legally confined to dealing with matters solely concerned with the wages and conditions of its members. But the unions are not so confined. The unions take it upon themselves-there is no legal restraint on them-to carry out actions far wider than those necessary for the wages and conditions of their members. They take political actions. They take other actions which are far wider than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which ones are these?
—I suggested political strike action-
—Which unions?
—One such as the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union and other prominant unions.
—This legislation will not affect them in the slightest.
—Does the honourable senator mean on compulsory unionism?
—Yes, because they have compulsory unionism on the job. Be sensible about it.

—Perhaps Senator Harradine and I can have a duologue on this. I said earlier when the honourable senator was not in the chamber that I am not opposed to compulsory unionism. I think it is appropriate if we can confine the union to dealing with matters that fall within its terms of reference or its proper sphere of action with regard to the wages and conditions of employment of members. Once it gets beyond that I think it is inappropriate to make the membership compulsory. I accept that in many unions there is de facto compulsory unionism. I would hate, for instance, to be a painter and docker in Victoria and refuse to join the union. I would watch my back very carefully when I walked around the streets of Port Melbourne. Therefore, that is a fact that we have to recognise. I would like to see this accepted as an interim phase, but that we should accept, if we can negotiate it with the trade union movement, that the trade unions will be legally limited to dealing with matters that concern their industrial behaviour. Then I would personally be prepared to support compulsory unionism. At the moment what the Minister has done is to accept the reality of the industrial situation as it is, where the unions are claiming far wider powers and activities than that. In those circumstances I do not think he could reasonably suggest that we should compel people to be members of the union.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one other area in which I believe the Government must give a lead. People are looking for someone to try to sort out this mess. One other area in which the Government must give a lead is to set its own house in order. After all, the Federal Government is by far the biggest employer of labour in the country. It must set an example. Commonwealth public servants are a special type of employee. They are servants of the public. It is a clear absurdity for them to be striking against the public that they are supposed to be serving. In my view, such behaviour is as unacceptable as it is for the Defence Force to mutiny .

In compensation for the restrictions imposed by their special status, public servants have great benefits. They have-despite the Commonwealth Employees ( Redeployment and Retirement) Act-virtual job tenure for their working life, except for dishonesty or gross incompetence. Even in the latter case it is difficult to effect a discharge. They are promised 'fair comparability' of wages and working conditions. They have an extremely generous indexed superannuation scheme, of a generosity which could not possibly be matched by any employer other than the Government. Trans Australia Airlines, by a decision of the Whitlam Government, was obliged to give Commonwealth-level superannuation to employees. One can see that if it were to meet its requirements it would be bankrupt. There is no way in which a private enterprise employer could give the superannuation benefits that are available to Commonwealth employees.

There has been-or rather, there was-a long tradition that public servants did not strike. This has gone by the board in recent years, although, to their great credit, a large number of public servants, perhaps a majority, refuse to be involved in any such prostitution of their profession. The militants must not be permitted to have it both ways. If they want to use the methods of the industrial jungle to extort from the public they are supposed to be serving, if they want to extort pay and working conditions in excess of what the Public Service Arbitrator considers fairly comparable with private sector employment, then they must give up the special compensations they receive-their security of tenure, and their extraordinarily generous superannuation scheme.

I suggest that all new recruits to the Commonwealth Public Service should be required to give a 'no strike' undertaking. Breach of this undertaking should result in instant dismissal. If they want to withdraw their labour, they should withdraw it right out of the Public Service. Existing public servants should be given an opportunity to sign a 'no strike' undertaking. If they do, they would deserve and continue to receive the compensating benefits of job security and superannuation. For those who refuse, and who, therefore, wish to be able to indulge in industrial blackmail, they should lose job security and should be forced into a special superannuation system, equivalent with those in private industry, with no indexation and with benefits related to contributions. This superannuation change could well save the taxpayer hundreds of millions of dollars a year, which would be some compensation for the injuries inflicted on them by their so-called servants. Some may say that this would be a retrospective change in conditions. So it would, but the change came when public servants started to strike against the public. These changes would merely bring conditions into line with behaviour.

It is, of course, implicit in having a 'no strike' requirement for public servants that they be treated fairly as regards wages and working conditions. As I said earlier, the Government has accepted fair comparability between the Public Service and the private sector. The machinery must be checked to ensure that discrepancies come promptly before the Public Service Arbitrator. But the umpire's decision must then be accepted.

I have one final point on this issue. Work bans-the refusal to do particular types of work which are normally carried out by the public servant-are a most pernicious development. It is absurd that public servants should refuse to do their job and yet remain at work on full pay. Stand downs without pay should be automatic and immediate, not held in reserve and used after hesitation and with much telegraphing of the punch. A work ban is a form of strike, and it will not go away if one pretends not to notice it.

So much for what the Government must do to restore its reputation as a responsible employer. This is only one matter on which the Government must give a lead. What the people are looking for in this area of industrial relations is leadership from the Government. We do not want confrontation. We want discussion , understanding and improvement but we will get that only if the Government is prepared to give, as it is giving, a lead in the necessary changes in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hamer said a lot about 'them and us' and I certainly believe the situation is one of 'them and us'. I agree with him when he refers to the excessive role of lawyers in the industrial process. The statement made by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) is the most recent development in the confrontationist campaign to reduce the standard of living of wage and salary earners. The Fraser Government is responsible for the situation in industrial relations today. The background to this statement is that in the field of industrial relations the Government's program is based on double talk and misinformation. On 16 January the Canberra Times reported that:

SPEECH.PARA: There was a strong indication of a softening of the Government's industrial- relations policy from legal sanctions to co-operation in an address by the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, in Sydney yesterday.
Mr Fraser told the national convention of the Young Liberals in Sydney that the establishment of a better industrial climate would be a major item for discussion at this month's talks with the ACTU.

That story was spread throughout Australia. Tonight we have the Government's statement before us in this chamber and it is the complete opposite. It shows the bias against the Labor movement. It will increase significantly the industrial disputes in this country. The Government states on page 11 of the statement:
. . . there is no room for any general wage increases to be granted in the national wage case and there should be no return to indexation.

It should be remembered that in the 15 national wage cases since 1975 the Fraser Government has opposed the Australian Council of Trade Unions' claim every time in that it has not supported full indexation, despite the pledge by the Liberal Prime Minister in 1975. This Government now seeks an industry by industry solution, it says, but I will show honourable senators that this is far from the truth because the Government has a mixed bag of inconsistent propositions. Its strategy is still the same. With the usual euphemisms, the statement says that the industry by industry negotiations appear to offer 'a real chance of containing the rate of inflation'. In other words, it is an attempt to prevent wages increasing at all. The significance of this statement can only be judged when we examine the new weapon of the Fraser Government-the enterprise union. A union in every work place is the threat of the proposals in this paper. This is a probable result of Senator Hamer and other senators and government advisers going to Japan. It is an importation we do not want from Japan.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't want them.

—If the Minister for Veterans' Affairs wants the Japanese company unions then we in the Labor movement certainly will not accept them. The Australian wage and salary earners will reject company unions. They are simply not acceptable. They are un-Australian. They are alien and they will be rejected by the Australian people. But the Prime Minister has released his kamikaze pilot . I do not know whether the Minister for Veterans' Affairs wants to join him. There will be a great deal of destruction in what this Government will do if it goes ahead with legislation based on this paper. The trade union movement must defend its coverage, its economic interest and the interests of people in competing companies.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us consider this proposal for a moment. In one street there could be two companies. One company could persuade its workers to join the company's union and there could be a complete mess because the companies could be doing exactly the same thing. From my experience as a former union official I can say that the first person to complain will be the company disaffected. It will complain about the company that gets an economic edge because of the exploitation of people in these so-called enterprise organisations. I well remember in the early 1950s a friend of mine in the advertising industry trying to form a union in that industry. He was going great guns. He had 800 people signed up when all of a sudden he realised that people were being encouraged by employers to join the company-style union because of the proposal for the Federated Clerks Union of Australia to be given coverage in the advertising industry. Of course, he immediately realised that he was being used and withdrew from the situation. The clerks gained that coverage. That is the sort of thing that will be occurring in Australia.

Enterprise unions mean turmoil in industry. Instead of the 300-odd unions we have now, the potential is for 2,000 unions. Anybody who believes in any order in the system-and that is what honourable senators opposite claim they believe in-should consider for a moment the paper work involved in such a situation. But , of course, they do not really want 2,000 unions. What they want to do is to weaken the trade union movement. The enterprise unions, so-called, are just the opposite to the policy of the Australian Labor party and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. No decent trade union organisation would allow people to be denied the resources of research and advocacy that the official trade union movement in this country represents at the moment. It is most mischievous of the Minister for Industrial Relations to say on page 19 of the statement that the objective in the paper is similiar to the objectives of the Labour movement. In practice the position is that industry-based unions come as the result of painstaking discussion and negotiation. The Liberal-National Country Party governments have caused difficulties in this process. The current frustration of union amalgamation is the result of this Government's anti-union bias.

I speak with some experience in this area. I was involved in the State and national discussions between two printing unions as the Secretary of the New South Wales branch of the printing trade union. In fact over six years of careful negotiations and the use of the democratic process we amalgamated the two printing unions. The result was the Printing and Kindred Industries Union, a union that my colleague Senator Tony Mulvihill correctly congratulated on being the result of a proper amalgamation process and a union that was then capable of dealing with the tremendous problems of technological change in the newspaper, magazine and other sections of the printing industry. That would have been impossible without the amalgamation of the printing unions on an industry basis. This is the sort of policy that is carried forward in the ACTU and Labor Party platforms. It is the sort of union that gives protection to people all over Australia, whether they be in large or small enterprises. It is the sort of organisation that we need in this country.

The Government's paper will only create anarchy. The Government's proposal contains the concept of a potential of 2,000 unions. I think we should consider for a moment what company unions mean. The use of the threat of sacking people or the taking away from them of reasonable promotion possibilities will be the order of the day. Conversely, union activists in a company union can expect all the worst jobs and even little things such as not getting overtime. Anybody with industrial experience knows that there are a hundred ways of discriminating against people who are activists in trade unions. The Viner plan invites racism. Every type of person can be disadvantaged. Women, people of ethnic backgrounds, the old, the young-all are vulnerable under the proposal that this Government puts forward because they will all be members of company unions in which there will be perhaps 100 people. Who would be the secretary of a small company union of fewer than 100 people? I suggest that the identikit picture of the secretary of an enterprise union is that of a pannikin boss, a crawler or some other person of that nature-certainly the sort of person who is unacceptable in the labour movement.

The trade union movement is berated in the Minister's statement. The vast majority of people in the trade union movement are fine Australians serving their colleagues and their country. The officials of trade unions in the vast majority of cases bring to an individual factory skill and objectivity. They also personify all the other people in that industry. That is the very thing that this Government wants to take away with its proposal for company organisations. That is the very thing that Australian workers will reject.

The paper that has been presented is a very interesting one. It has 23 pages. Because of my printing background I could not but look at the sub-headings. There are only two of them in 23 pages. The first sub-heading says 'What Lies Ahead'. Of course, the next paragraph gives it away, because it states:
The Government's policies over recent years have achieved considerable success in bringing about economic recovery.

What this Government says lies ahead are in fact the same lies that are behind it. Throughout the Minister's statement there is this continuing deceit about who is causing the problem. It is this Government that has destroyed the consensus on wage indexation. It destroyed it deliberately, and now the Minister says that there should be no return to indexation. For all its faults, indexation did give aid to workers in weak sections of industry. The Government destroyed that aid. Now it wants to destroy those workers' organisation totally by forcing them into tame cat enterprise unions.

The reason for the rise in industrial disputes is simple-living standards are falling. The Fraser Government is responsible. Recently interest rates have risen to record levels. We must not forget that as interest rates rise, so do repayment rates. Even worse, home buyers who may have a loan that takes up to, say, a quarter of their wage would need to get a wage rise four times greater than the rise in interest on their loan. This is compounded by the lack of tax indexation whereby, because of heavy taxes, workers need a rise significantly higher than the rate of inflation to stay afloat. The Government has said a lot about inflationary expectations. But what about tax expectations? The Government 's already severe cuts in the social wage of health and welfare benefits have been added to by sales taxes. This year the average household will pay $2,460 in indirect taxes in 1981-82 prices. On the same basis they paid only $1,950 in 1975-76. The major money lenders, the big banks, are doing very well out of those monetarist policies described by one cynic as tight money, loose regulation and a warm place to count the profits. That really is symptomatic of this government, but the banks are doing very well indeed. The results of last financial year for the big five free enterprise banks show a total profit of $ 531m, an increase of 30 per cent in one year. Over the past five years profits have increased by $370m, or well over threefold. Australians know who is holding us to ransom. Bank profits are far in excess of any wage increases or of inflation. Bank profits have in fact been increasing at about three times the rate of increase in average weekly earnings and average company profits over the last six years, as Maximilian Walsh points out in the journal Australian Business.

The Government talks about union power. Which union has the power that the Broken Hill Pty Co. Ltd has at Whyalla or Port Kembla or that the banks I have described have? The top 200 companies get 40 per cent of the profits generated in Australia. The bottom 32,000 companies get the other 60 per cent. The Government has the power to prevent this but it does not do so. Instead it sabotages indexation and then attacks the unions, as it is doing at present. As I have said, it opposed every one of the 15 ACTU applications for full indexation in the national wage cases. It mouths words such as 'justice' and ' responsibility' when it really means wage restraint. That is the essence of the document before us today. It is, I suggest to Senator Hamer, a case of 'them' and 'us'.

Economic recovery is a mirage. The Government claims in the paper that over two years the economy has created a quarter of a million jobs. The facts are that this Government has created half a million unemployed at least. Inflation is up to 11 per cent and the Treasury itself blames the latest jump on 'a number of government taxes and charges'. That is the essence of current industrial unrest. The Government claims that wages threaten the recovery and that real wages have risen in the recent past. Looking at the long term we can see that since 1975-76 productivity has risen by 6 per cent and real wages have fallen by 2 per cent. The recent Treasury 'Roundup of Economic Statistics' says that growth in employment is slowing down. The Government's economic policy is a disaster.

On page 14 of the Minister's statement the Government refers to a recent agreement on wages and hours in the printing industry. The agreement provides for wage increases and reduced working hours in the printing industry. The Minister's opposition to the union's agreement with several thousand employers in the printing industry is an indication of the Fraser Government's attitude to a real agreement by people who know the problems of an industry. It gives the lie to the Government's claim that it is interested in industry agreements.

This Government's lack of planning in the field of technological change is incredible. It is well known. The productivity increases achieved through technological change have been dramatic. This is particularly so in the newspaper, printing and packaging industry. The Australian Financial Review on 11 March 1980 reported that in the printing industry in 1979-80 real wages were down by 9.1 per cent, employment was down by 6.9 per cent, productivity was up by 6.6 per cent and profits were up by 15.7 per cent. The Australian Bureau of Statistics pointed out that the basic tradesman's average real wage fell by $3. 38. At the same time, in 1980 the Australian Financial Review reported in its Survey of Annual Profitability report that four out of five companies had increased profits. Two companies in five had increased their profits from 10 per cent to 50 per cent. This Government cannot stop the movement of industries in this direction. I was a tradesman in this industry 20 years ago. The changes in technique and the increases in productivity that have taken place are incredible . Yet the printing industry dispute, if it can be called that, has been resolved by an agreement. Only five and a half working days were lost between April and October last year through industrial disputation in that industry. Essentially those days were taken up by report-back meetings with the people involved.

The Fraser Government is creating a smokescreen over industrial relations. Nothing is more typical than an article in last Sunday's issue of the Sunday Telegraph from the Murdoch stable. The article is headed 'Strikers' Wives get $ 2m'. Of course, it is a regurgitation of Senator Chaney's statement in this chamber last year when he mentioned six disputes and claimed that the community was subsidising them through the welfare system. Let us look at some of those disputes. One involved the Utah company, the profits of which were described in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday as 'enormous and amazing'. Honourable senators will recall the enormous funds this company shipped to its United States parent several years ago. There was no talk of preventing this blatant rip-off by the company. Another dispute mentioned by Senator Chaney involved Nabalco Pty Ltd at Gove. This company has recently been questioned by the Icelandic Government about alleged transfer pricing of profits out of Australia. What will the Government do about this? It is a case of 'them and us'. It is the difference between who the Government favours and what it is doing in the proposed industrial package set out in the Minister's statement.

I could go on and on but the facts are simple: The Government does not give a damn about transnational companies. It thinks it is okay for Utah to ship $100m out of Australia in one year if Utah wants to do so. But if an industrial worker tries to get $20 a week more because he has to pay higher rent or higher interest rates on his home loan, because of rising costs of necessities, crippling petrol prices and, of course, higher taxation--

TALK.START.PARA: —Or even $56 a week.

—It might be $50 the way the Government is going. The money means nothing if what is known as the social wage has increased. The cost of health care, the cost of education, the cost of every necessity of life have increased because of this Government's action. The Government's own advisers, in the report of the Interdepartmental Committee on Economic Strategy released in 1980, said just that. The report reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the overall burden of taxation (as a proportion of GDP) has increased.

That is the answer. Let us not hear any rubbish about taxation having fallen. This is quite apart from the crippling sales taxes that the Government has already imposed and seeks still to impose. It is undeniable that for the Government to attack wage and salary earners who try to defend their standard of living is cruel hypocrisy. Even more hypoctitical is the following claim on page 17 of the Minister's statement:
. . . that no section of the community can be above the law.
What a statement! I shall repeat it:
. . . that no section of the community can be above the law.

The fact is that any executive or professional with a good accountant is way above the law. Billions of dollars are slipping through to tax avoiders while the Government tries to tell us that only a few hundred million dollars-it's $ 973m-is involved. The people who are above the law are not the strikers and not their spouses but the friends of the Fraser Government. My authority on this matter is none other than Eric Risstrom, Secretary to the Australian Taxpayers Association. He estimates that tax evasion and avoidance cost the community $7 billion a year. This is one of the few growth industries in Australia. That represents $30 a week for every household in this country. That is where the $20 -or $50 according to the honourable senator-is chasing its tail, because $30 a week from every householder is being forgone by this Government. It is the friend of tax avoiders. It has introduced this statement in order to try to place the blame on to the shoulders of wage and salary earners. The Australian people will reject it. If the presentation of the paper has something to do with the Lowe by-election, the Government is acting very foolishly because it has tampered with something that is far too serious to be involved in a cheap political trick. I hope that the Government does not go ahead with the proposals foreshadowed in its statement. If it does it will do so at its peril.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President-(Quorum formed). I believe that the debate really centres on whether there is some connection between the present problems faced by the Australian people in relation to the economy and the industrial relations problem that is also faced by them. Firstly , I wish to make it perfectly clear that I am not talking about the types of union to which Senator Elstob was referring. I am not talking about the moderate unions which make up by far the majority of unions in Australia. I am not talking about the unions the executives of which are not interested in doing away with our democratic way of life. I am talking about the Halfpennys, the Carmichaels, the Gallaghers and those radical unions that we all know only too well. They are dedicated to the destruction of our way of life and the democracy that we know only too well. If there are any doubts in the minds of honourable senators opposite that what I am saying is true, let me refresh their memories of what happened two months ago. Senator Lewis referred to this matter but I will elaborate on it. An article in the Australian Financial Review stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Continued industrial strife on the Australian waterfront has forced the world's largest insurer of losses to shipowners . . . to take the unprecedented step of suspending insurance for ships operating in Australian waters.

The London-based Shipowners Mutual Strike Assurance Association has telexed the Australian Chamber of Shipping saying it has given one month's notice of termination 'to all its Australian members and to non-Australian members trading to that continent with bad records'.
In its telex the association expressed 'deep regret' with the move which, according to the Chamber of Shipping, will affect all major shipowners operating vessels to Australia.

The executive director of the Chamber of Shipping . . . said the decision means , that from 31 January 1982, shipowners trading to Australia will lose their strike protection insurance unless they are prepared to accept punitive loadings on premiums . . .
In its telex, the association said that cover would only be offered to prospective members if they were prepared to have claims arising in Australian waters excluded.

The telex said that current members would be offered renewals but on a much restricted basis with heavily loaded rates which, it said, 'surely in the long term have a serious effect on Australia's ability to export'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was responsible for all that?

—The Amalgamated Metalworkers and Shipwrights Union was responsible. We did not have in 1981 one day free of some major confrontation on our waterfront. When we have a reputation in the world like that, and when big companies say that they will not insure our shipping freight, it results only in more ships doing what some ships already do; that is, pick up our exports in Singapore. The ships will not even come within our waters. As I have already said, this results in higher freight costs and less competition.

SPEECH.PARA: Some time ago I spoke in this place about the effect of the problems on our waterfront on the apple industry. I will refresh the memories of honourable senators on this matter. Let us compare Australia with New Zealand. The cost of loading a carton of apples in that country is $US.325. In Tasmania it is $US1.16 . The total freight cost to get that carton of apples to England is $6.50. What on earth will the lack of insurance on ships coming within Australian waters do to that amount of $6.50? No foreign ships will come to pick up our apples. What will the resulting freight increase do to the apple industry in Tasmania? It is already in a disastrous state. What on earth will the tremendous increase in freight do to our competition, with New Zealand, for example? Less competition will mean fewer jobs. Yet I have not heard one Australian Labor party senator mention the unemployment rate during this debate. They are just not interested. They did not mention unemployment problems at all. All they are interested in doing is increasing benefits to those people who have jobs. They are not interested in the fact that if our exports are less competitive more people will be unemployed and fewer jobs will be available. It did not enter their heads.

We have been told every time we mention industrial relations that we are union bashing. As a matter of fact, Mr Hayden and Mr Wran did not get together with their public statements the other day. Mr Hayden accused Mr Fraser of union bashing because he dared to mention a few of the problems we have in this country with the unions. On the same news item, Mr Wran was quoted as saying that there was a touch of lunacy and that there might be some bloody mindedness within the union movement. He was not accused of union bashing by Mr Hayden, perhaps they were at odds with each other. As Senator Lewis said, the cost of these strikes is prohibitive to this country. We are losing $1.5m a day on the waterfront. Senator Lewis went into the details even more thoroughly. The cost in wages to the unionists alone is prohibitive. The unionists themselves do not want to go on strike. It is the executive-the Halfpennys, the Carmichaels and the Gallaghers-which forces the unionists into striking.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get out the old record.

—I have been told that I am getting out the old record. It might not be a bad idea if honourable senators opposite occasionally listened to the record. It is that group which is undermining the whole economy of this country, not by accident-there is nothing accidental about it-but very deliberately. If we dare mention any of those radical unions we are told it is confrontation. Of course, it is never said that the unions might be indulging in a little confrontation. It is always this Government which is indulging in confrontation.

SPEECH.PARA: On 8 December Mr Carmichael announced that he had a new metal trades agreement. He was very careful to say that the new agreement was a great step forward but the union would not give up the right to strike. It would give up the right to strike for dollars but it would not give up the right to strike. That is very important. He has assured us that the union is giving up the right to strike on wages but not on political matters, because political matters will bring down this country when unionists take it into their own hands to take political decisions which are nothing to do with a true union movement. On 9 February, in conjunction with Mr Hayden, he said that his union had had a rethink about the dollar strike because now it wanted a social wage. What did Mr Hayden do? Mr Hayden welcomed that statement by the AMWSU. He welcomed Mr Carmichael when he said: 'Good. This is what our Labor Government wants'. Mr Carmichael, for some reason or other, thinks that he only confronts this Government when he indulges in a campaign for a social wage. Whenever he indulges in any campaign at all he naturally hurts his own members, who lose wages, and he also hurts employers. We could not possibly give any credence to any promise that that man is likely to give.

Both the Australian Democrats and the Labor Party have said that they will not support the stand-down clause. This has already worked and worked well in the Public Service. For some time now we have used the stand-down clauses and they have been effective. If 10 people out of a work force of 200 employed by a company or business go on strike and thus prevent the remainder of the work force working, I see no reason why those 190 employees who do not have a job to do should be paid just to turn up. I believe that if we introduce this stand- down clause those 10 striking employees may think twice about putting all their mates out of a job. I think there would be enough pressure from their mates for them to say: 'Think again. Let us act through the arbitration court and not take strike action'.

The Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) said in his statement that there should be more equal bargaining. We know-and I am sure that Senator Elstob would agree-that whenever the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission hands down a decision employers abide by it. They never say: 'We are not going to abide by that. We are going to lock our doors'. The employers have never done that but the unions do it whenever they feel like it. When the Arbitration Commission brings down a decision the unions abide by it if they want to; if they do not want to abide by it they say: 'Not on your life. We will go on strike'! What sort of equal bargaining power is that?

TALK.START.PARA: —What sort of government is it?

—Senator Sibraa says: 'What sort of government is it?' He is intending to convey that we have no control over the situation. Let us have a look at the record-I am very happy to look at the records-of the Labor Party in 1974 when the highest number of working days were lost for the last 10 years.
—That is not right.

—Senator Elstob says: 'That is not right'. The honourable senator does not believe in the Australian Bureau of Statistics. Do not tell me that the Australian Bureau of Statistics data is incorrect because nobody else in Australia would agree. In 1974 in Labor's term there were 6.2 million days lost through industrial disputes. I ask the honourable senators to compare that figure with the figures either before or after 1974. In 1980, the last year for which we have full data, 3.3 million working days were lost.
—What is it this year?

—We do not have the figures for last year yet and the honourable senator knows that darn well. Nearly twice as many days were lost under the Labor Government as were lost in the last year for which we have records. Yesterday Senator Button told us that he knew how to work it all out. Today we have had lessons from the Opposition on what we should do. But let us look at the record and we will see who has the worst record. Honourable senators will find that the worst result was recorded the last time the Labor Party was in government.
—Because more people were working. They are all out of work now.

—Do not tell us how we should work. Do not tell us you are crash hot on industrial relations. History proves that the Labor Party is no good and that at least we are doing something about the situation. I have dealt with the need for standowns. I think the Australian people believe that they are justified. Standowns have worked within the Commonwealth context and I believe they will substantially help industrial relations generally. I turn to union amalgamations. It seems there is some sort of agreement between the Labor Party and the Liberal party on industry based unions, but there we seem to part company because Senator Childs has said that the Labor party does not believe in enterprise unions. He did not say why. He just said that he did not believe in them.
—Yes he did. You were not paying attention.

—I was paying attention and the honourable senator did not give any details as to why the Labor Party did not believe in them. He just said that it was something the ALP did not believe in; it was something that we had brought from Japan and he felt that we were playing around with it. It is an interesting idea. I believe that we can have successful enterprise unions. We do not need to amalgamate to get them. As was said earlier, I can foresee that perhaps Fletcher Jones and Staff Pty Ltd could set up its own union. It has worker participation that is the envy of a lot of companies. There is no reason for their employees not to set up their own enterprise based union.
—What is an enterprise based union? What do you mean?
—I cannot explain it any clearer than I have.
—What is it you keep repeating?

—If Senator McIntosh is not capable of understanding perhaps he can read Hansard tomorrow. Fletcher Jones would be a typical example of what I believe would be a very good enterprise based union, should it desire to set it up. Senator Button, who last year brought down legislation, seemed to want amalgamation for amalgamation's sake. He was quite willing to-
—He brought down your Government's legislation.
—Why don't you read Hansard?

—I have certainly read Hansard. It is legislation that we discarded and voted against and I certainly have never been in agreement with it . I do not believe we should say that only 25 per cent of a union need vote and that if only half of those vote for amalgamation then amalgamation will take place. This results in only 12 1/2 per cent of a union having a right to say: ' We will amalgamate'. That sort of democracy is not the sort of democracy that I am interested in.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to voluntary unionism. I am well aware that voluntary unionism is not one of Senator Harradine's pet hobbies. I believe he justifiably puts forward his views. If we look at the matter we will see that it is a question of philosophy. The Labor Party, being a socialist party, feels that people should be forced to do certain things that a socialist government believes they should do. We as a Government say that we believe people should be able to please themselves. We do not believe that people should have to join an organisation if they do not want to join it. Every time I hear people say: 'We will force people to belong to an organisation', I object. Compulsory unionism means that if one does not join a union one does not get a job. I cannot go along with compulsory unionism. Union preference is, I believe, compulsory unionism because unless one belongs to a union one does not get a job.

TALK.START.PARA: —The High Court has denied that.

—I am sorry, I disagree entirely with Senator Harradine's concept. I believe that our philosophy which states that nobody should be forced to join a union is 100 per cent right. The last thing I want to mention is the present situation that exists in New South Wales. Mr Wran, in New South Wales, played along with unions in the Electricity Commission of New South Wales. He said to the unions: 'Righto, we will give you a 37 1/2-hour week'. That was in 1980. In 1981 it was down to a 35-hour week. Now what sort of position is the Electricity Commission in? Those workers promised extra productivity but what has happened? All maintenance has been put aside. With a 35-hour week there was no way that they could carry out the maintenance in the time required. Now Mr Wran says that he is sorry that electricity is not available but that it is all the fault of the unions. Indeed, it was all Mr Wran's fault. If Mr Wran had not handed down a 35-hour week then the maintenance would have been carried out and New South Wales would not be in the situation it is in. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 18 January 1982 which Senator Gietzelt might find interesting states:

SPEECH.PARA: In November, 1980, Neville wran, under attack from the Opposition over the introduction of a 37 1/2-hour week in the Electricity Commission, invited the people of NSW to make a comparison between electricity supplies in NSW and Victoria.

''So bad has been the planning under a Liberal Government that, within another two and a half to three years, Victoria will face a bleak prospect of intermittent blackout,'' the Premier said. ''That cannot be said in NSW.''

What has happened now? New South Wales is buying electricity from Victoria. So much for the industrial relations of the Premier of New South Wales. He handed those workers a 35-hour week in return for promises of extra productivity but they cannot carry out the necessary maintenance in a 35-hour week. As a result that State has ended up having blackouts that are absolutely disastrous. The Australian Labor Party is dead scared of touching the unions. The Labor Party will never mention union irresponsibility. It is dead scared it will lose the money it receives for elections if it does. It is supported financially by radical union mobs and it is dead scared of being critical of them at all. It is a sorry state in this country when the union movement absolutely runs the Labor Party because of financial commitments.

I come back to my original point. I have proved that the economy of this country is ravaged by industrial unrest. Completely irresponsible unions are, not accidentally, but deliberately, trying to destroy our way of life. If the Government does not take some action then I believe that it is irresponsible.
