TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. (1) Page 1, clause 3, line 21, after 'Northern Territory' insert 'or Norfolk Island'.
2. (2) Page 2, clause 3, line 6, after 'court', insert ', the Northern Territory or the Administration of an external Territory'.
3. (3) Page 2, clause 3, lines 15 and 16, leave out paragraph (e), substitute ' (e) the Administration of an external Territory other than Norfolk Island;'.

By way of explanation for honourable senators who are taking part in this debate which has been sprung on the Senate at a late hour this evening as a result of the important debate that has been going on on industrial relations having been taken out of the hands of the Government, we are now proceeding to deal with amendments to the Archives Bill which reached Committee stage some time ago. Many amendments to the the Bill have been foreshadowed by the Government, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. The Senate Clerks have very helpfully prepared a detailed schedule of these amendments clause by clause, identifying Government amendments in printed form, Opposition amendments in small type and Australian Democrat amendments in large type.

TALK.START.PARA: —A first-class job.

—It is a very good job and I am glad that Senator Chipp appreciates it as much as I certainly do. I think this will facilitate progress in what will be a rather difficult technical exercise which surprisingly has been thrust upon the Senate, contrary to the arrangements of the day, at a late hour this evening. The first three amendments on the list are Government amendments to clause 3. Their object is to exclude bodies established under a law of Norfolk Island from the operation of the Archives Bill. This is in accordance with the Freedom of Information Bill and recognising that Norfolk Island is in the initial stages of transition to full self-government and that access to government information is a matter for local administration.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4. (5) Page 2, clause 3, sub-clause (1), line 10, defintion of 'Commonwealth institution', after 'including' insert 'the Executive Council,'.
5. (6) Page 2, clause 3, sub-clause (1), definition of 'Commonwealth institution', after paragraph (a) insert the following new paragraph:
''(aa) the Governor-General;''.

Amendments 4 and 5 on the consolidated list are the first Opposition amendments in what will be quite a long process of consideration of the Archives Bill by this chamber in Committee. I very briefly, though I will not enter in any sense into a recap of the second reading debate given the time that has elapsed, indicate that the Opposition, whilst commending the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) for bring in an Archives Bill which at last gives a statutory framework and a legislative scheme for the Australian Archives to operate under, and agreeing in princple, finds that much of the Bill is deficient in that the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs have in so many instances-some 35 that the Opposition is concerned about -been ignored. It is in relation to those 35 recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee that the Opposition will move its amendments.

I make that point because I think honourable senators on all sides of the chamber ought to be aware that the amendments to be moved by the Australian Democrats or by Australian Labor Party senators are not of their own whim or fancy or in any sense partisan. They are simply bringing to the chamber recommendations from the Senate Standing Committee which is itself a bipartisan committee of six distinguished members of this chamber under the leadership of Senator Missen, in the case of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, and former Senator Davidson in the case of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts. All these amendments are brought forward on behalf, in a sense, of those Senate standing committees.

Amendments 4 and 5 are to do with definitional clauses and simply insert in the definition of 'Commonwealth institution' the words 'the Executive Council' and the words 'the Governor-General'. Later on in the Bill where the words 'records of a Commonwealth institution' occur that has the effect of ensuring that records belonging to the Executive Council and the Governor-General will come within the purview of the Bill. At the moment only records belonging to a Commonwealth institution as defined in clause 3 came within the purview of the Bill. 'Commonwealth institution' is defined in the Bill as:
a body, other than a State, established by or in accordance with the Constitution, including the Senate, the House of Representatives and the High Court;

Records of those institutions are records of a Commonwealth institution. Records of a department, of a Federal court or a court of a Territory will come within the purview of the Bill. Records of an authority of the Commonwealth and records of the Administration of a territory other than the Northern Territory or Norfolk Island-this will be covered by a government amendment to be moved a little later-are included under 'Commonwealth institution'. We propose that records belonging to the Governor-General and the Executive Council should come within the purview of the Bill. We will explain in greater detail later when we come to the substantive clauses dealing with the attempt by this Bill to exclude records of the Governor-General and the Executive Council why that should be so.

Very briefly, we are dealing here with records which are 30 years of age or older. I emphasise that point. We are not dealing for example with records of the Governor-General or the Executive Council of a currency in political terms; we are dealing with historical documents which lie probably at the very heart of the history of this nation. Records of the Governor-General and of the Executive Council must be the very essence of the history of the governments of Australia. For that reason we believe that 30 years-or 25 years after 5 years if an Australian Democrats amendment to be moved in a moment passes-should be available for consideration by historians and by those who have an interest in our history. This is merely a definitional matter but it is the first of those matters which arise out of the Senate commitee reports. I commend the amendments to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not go into the substance of the matter before Senator Missen if he wishes to speak ahead of me. But I have a difficulty. It is one that will arise throughout consideration of this complicated series of amendments because we are now dealing with amendments which are part of a series of amendments that raise some major issues of policy in relation to the Archives Bill. On the face of it one of the amendments seems simply to be widening the definition of 'Commonwealth institution' to include the Executive Council. There may be some debate for and against that. To debate this in that narrow way would really miss the point of what the amendment is about. The amendment is part of amendments which have wider policy implications.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to waste the time of the Committe by debating whether the definition 'Commonwealth institution' should be expanded to include the Executive Council without us really debating the issue why the definition of ' Commonwealth institution' is to be expanded to include it. I raise this as a matter which I think the Committee perhaps ought to consider. We have a first amendment which is one of a series of amendments which are scattered throughout this long list and are not grouped together. It has been decided that we will not proceed in that way. Nevertheless we do not want unrealistic debate on a particular amendment. I suggest for consideration of the Committee that when we have an amendment like this which is one of a group we have a policy debate in relation to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I indicated in my opening remarks that indeed I realised that in a sense we were not merely dealing with a definitional clause but that, in fact, this would have repercussions throughout the consideration of the Archives Bill. We are bringing about a situation in which, wherever the words 'records of a Commonwealth institution' occur throughout the Bill we will be referring, amongst other things, to the possibility that records belonging to the Executive Council or a Governor-General will become subject to the Bill. Everyone knows what the clauses of the Bill purport to do-they purport to make available such records to the general public as of right after the lapse of 30 years, as the Bill is presently drafted, and perhaps after a quarter of a century after five years if the Australian Democrats amendment is accepted. I would have thought it was perfectly plain, so that when one comes to read about the ability of the Archives to seek the transfer of record of documents from a Commonwealth institution to Archives it will now include the records of the Executive Council or Governor-General. Everyone can comprehend that. That is the nature of the definitional section. Where it is stated that all records in the possession of the Archives or a Commonwealth institution in the open access period shall become available to the public as of right, we now know that amongst other Commonwealth institutions, such as this Senate chamber or the High Court which is presently provided for, we additionally will include the records of the Governor-General or the Executive Council. That is the nature of the definitional section.

SPEECH.PARA: As to why the records of the Governor-General or the Executive Council should be available, I simply reiterate the point that was made in evidence time and again by historians before the Committee, namely, that to exclude these records would be like trying to understand-I think this is what one of the historians said to us-the history of a company without having the minutes of the board of directors. Here we have the very essence of the governance of this country. Therefore it is extremely important that they fall within the purview of the Act in a way which, if other amendments are carried as put forward by the Opposition and the Australian Democrats, those records will be available, as I said, as of right. At the present moment the Bill purports to exclude entirely from the operation of the open access provisions records of the Governor-General and records of the Executive Council. Furthermore, it does so conclusively. There is no way at the present moment whereby an historian who wants access to those records of 30 years of age or over can go to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and seek a reversal of the decision to prevent him from having access to those documents. The fact is that we are here setting the basis in a definitional clause, as is necessary at the beginning of the Bill, for those further amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —In considering these two amendments I suggest that the Committee take into account the remarks that have been made by Senator Tate and the Attorney-General. I assure honourable senators that the Chair will be liberal in its interpretation of any point of order that might be taken in respect of the matter that has been raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I desire to speak briefly on this amendment and to indicate my attitude to the whole series of amendments that are before the chamber during the committee stage of this debate. Honourable senators have to understand that the committee stage of this debate follows the fact that of the three Bills, the two major ones were referred to the Senate Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, which reported in November 1979. I was Chairman of that committee. I refer to the report which is before us-a very massive report. It was one of the largest investigations ever done by a committee of this Parliament. I stand by the recommendations of that committee. There are many features of the Archives Bill which are in the same area as the Freedom of Information Bill, in particular those relating to access to documents . Other aspects of the Archives Bill were referred to the Senate Committee on Education and the Arts which was chaired by Senator Davidson. I am not referring to the amendments that relate to that area, but I am concerned with the recommendations which that Senate Committee unanimously made and which are contained in the report. That committee consisted of three Liberal senators- Senator Hamer, Senator Puplick and myself-and three Labor senators.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition amendments are mostly a reflection of the implementation of the recommendations of the Senate Committee. It is true that a number of the Government amendments also do that to a certain degree. It should be explained that after the report of that Committee, when a new Bill was brought into the Parliament for freedom of information and for Archives, discussions took place between a number of Liberal senators, the Government and the Attorney-General ( Senator Durack), which ultimately resulted, in the course of the debate on the Freedom of Information Bill, in some compromise proposals which the Liberal senators accepted. Some of those proposals, particularly in regard to a documents review tribunal, have been transferred, quite appropriately, into the Archives Bill in accordance with that agreement. Consequently, as far as the Government amendments are concerned, I have no problem in supporting them. I think they are proper.

Although there are detailed negotiations with the Government and agreements were reached as far as the Freedom of Information Bill was concerned, we well know that that Bill has not yet passed through the House of Representatives. I trust that it will do so without any further delay. As the Bill left this chamber it did not incorporate all the agreements which were entered into with the Government by Liberal senators. I regret that. I have spoken about that and did so before I went overseas in June of last year. I have not ben successful in getting into that Bill those amendments, which are mainly related to public interest clauses. I am pleased to see that those amendments are in the Victorian Government's Bill. Regrettably, therefore, the record of the Government with respect to the completion of agreements with Liberal senators over the Freedom of Information Bill is unsatisfactory.

As far as this Bill is concerned, I have endeavoured for some nine monts to engage in discussions with the Government over the Committee's recommendations and the Opposition amendments when they came along. I have been unsuccessful in having any such discussions. Therefore, I do not propose to vote down amendments which my Senate Committee recommended unanimously. I believe that the recommendations in that report are still as sound today as they were when we delivered that report in November 1979. Since I have not had the courtesy or opportunity of discussing the matter or of finding out why they have been rejected-if they have been rejected; I suppose I must conclude that-I am afraid that so far as I am concerned I propose to abstain from voting on all the amendments relating to the implementation of my Committee's report. Basically, those are most of the amendments which the Labor Opposition is moving.

The amendments proposed by the Australian Democrats take this matter into different areas. I am sure that there is considerable merit in a number of their amendments. But these are not matters which my Committee has discussed. They are not matters which have been discussed by the Government. I do not propose to support those amendments. The result of this will be, I think, that possibly some amendments will be carried and the Government may not be willing to accept them. If so, the Government can explain to the House of Representatives why they will not be accepted. No doubt those amendments may be taken out in the House of Representatives. If so one must accept that that is as far as the Government wants to go and that is as good a Bill as we need.

We need to pass the Archives Bill through this Parliament. It has been delayed terribly. It is still here nine months after it probably should have been concluded. From this point of view I do not propose to engage in any detail in this debate. I will take an interest in the debate. Therefore, I propose to abstain from voting on the Labor Party's amendments, to oppose the amendments of the Australian Democrats and to support the Government amendments. I hope that the Government may see fit still to accept some of the recommendations that the Senate Committee put forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that other speakers want to debate this matter. I am not attempting to foreshorten the debate, not that I have any power to do so. Some people seem to think that when a Minister rises he is about to end the debate. I want to comment on one matter raised by Senator Missen. He has told us in broad terms what his attitude will be. That is all very interesting, but not altogether surprising. I propose to comment on one matter because I take grave exception to Senator Missen discussing what may have taken place between Liberal senators and the Government in relation to the freedom of information legislation. He chose to do so tonight and did so on a previous occasion. He alleges that agreements reached between Government senators were not carried forward fully into amendments that were moved by me on behalf of the Government in relation to the freedom of information legislation.
—That is right.

—That is what Senator Missen has said. The fact is that I entirely repudiate what he says. All other Government senators who have had anything to do with this Bill agree that the amendments which were moved by the Government carry out the agreement that was reached.
—That is not true.

—Senator Missen is the one witness saying that. No other Government senator has ever supported him. In all my conversations with them I was given to understand that none of them ever will. I want to make it quite clear that I am not going to sit here and listen to Senator Missen making completely wrong statements about what arrangements were made privately with Government senators in relation to another Bill months ago. I do not see what relevance it has to this debate. I hope that the matter may be regarded finally as closed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we leave clause 3 I would like to seek an assurance on a particular matter from the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). Before I do, perhaps it would clarify things and perhaps even help the Whips if I make clear where I stand as a member of the Senate committee which made a number of recommendations on this Bill. I stand by the recommendations. I think they were correct. They would make this a better Bill. On the other hand, as General Wolfe once said: 'War is an option of difficulties.' So is politics. I think we need an Archives Bill urgently. I think this is the best Bill we are going to get. I think it would be better if more of the recommendations of the Committee had been incorporated. Nevertheless, I am prepared to vote for and to accept the Bill as it is. When I say 'as it is', I mean with the Government's amendments which go a fair way, but by no means completely, towards adopting the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I leave clause 3 though, I would like to raise an issue that is causing great concern in the film industry, and that is the possible damage to the film archive of the National Library. It would be highly undesirable if we set up two competing film archives. The National Library film archive is an admirable organisation. It must be supported and must not be subverted or damaged by having a rival organisation in the Australian Archives. I would like an assurance from the Attorney-General. This assurance is necessary because the definition of 'record' on page 3 of the Bill provides for the inclusion of film 'that is, or has been, kept by reason of any information or matter that it contains or can be obtained from it or by reason of its connection with any event, person, circumstance or thing'. As that definition reads, it would appear possible for the National Archives to demand and keep films produced by the Australian Film Commission, the Australian Broadcasting Commission, Film Australia and other government producers. I think it must be made quite clear- and I ask the Attorney-General to do so-that this is not the intention of the Government and will not be the intention of the Australian Archives. Certainly the Australian Archives keep microfiche or film records in documentary form but films which are produced for exhibition, for viewing by the public, must not be part of the film archive. They must be part of the National Library archive. I would like an assurance from the Attorney-General that that will be the policy of the Government in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that Senator Missen, in spite of what he has said, with his usual fairness of mind, will, in the light of the discussion, look at our amendments on their merits. I am a little disappointed that in the early stages he has said that he proposes to vote against the amendments. The Australian Democrats certainly will be supporting substantially those amendments being moved by the Labor Party which are, in fact, the result of the work of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs . I hope that Senator Missen will extend the same courtesy to what we are doing here. But I understand; all of us here are slightly scarred by the trauma of the Freedom of Information Bill. I see the preface to these comments in this Committee stage as being due to that. With your permission, Mr Chairman, I simply call honourable senators' attention to the appalling and disgraceful way in which the Government used the closing hours of its control in this place to force through an enormous number of useful areas of the Freedom of Information Bill which ought to have been debated and discussed in this place but which were not. I will not forget or forgive that easily.
—We are bloodied but unbowed.

—Exactly. In dealing with this Archives Bill we are, of course, legislating for events which will happen well into the twenty-first century. I would hope that because of that we would have some hope for the future of the world and that we might be legislating for a time which is a good deal more liberal than our present time. Let us as least hope that it is not less liberal than at present. I feel that we would be justified in this place in at least having that degree of liberality whereby we felt that with caution we could achieve it. With all due hope, I do not think we will get terribly far beyond the Bill. Whatever little things we do I think will not change the course of history very substantially or shake the earth. On that basis, I think it only reasonable to expect that some amendments should be allowed to pass. I hope the Government sees the matter in that light rather than in a purely obstructive light. I think it would be terrible if that happened with this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Chairman, I would like to refer to clauses 4 and 5. I find what Senator Tate has said pursuasive. He is right. There is no reason why the Governor-General in Executive Council should not come within the purview of this Bill. If indeed there are reasons-and I think this is the key to the way in which we approach this matter; it is certainly the way in which the Australian Democrats will look at it-we would like to hear them. At this stage, and before we vote on the measure, I would like to hear from the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) good and cogent reasons why, indeed, well into the twenty-first century, records involving the Governor-General in Executive Council should not come within the purview of the Archives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak only briefly, in part to allay some of the fears of Senator Mason and also to anticipate some of the things which might be said by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). I invite the attention of honourable senators to consolidated amendment No. 26 which the Opposition intends to move and which provides a regulation-making power, subject to approval by each House of the Parliament, especially to protect certain records of the Governor-General and records in the possession of a court. This measure has been included in the amendment in particular because the Committee found that there was a case for protecting correspondence between the Monarch and the Governor-General-of course it is protected in the United Kingdom by vice -regal rules of 60 years' secrecy and so on-and also certain records in the possession of a court. The latter is a reference to judges' notebooks and so on; but it is irrelevant for this immediate purpose.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment contains some provision for a regulation-making power, with the concurrence of each House, to enable certain records of the Governor-General to be protected. I wanted to make that clear. Otherwise, the purpose of the definitional section being altered in the way in which we propose is to enable, in later operative sections of the Act, those documents to come within the purview of the Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal first with the point raised by Senator Hamer in relation to the definition of 'records ' which includes film. Concern has been expressed by a number of people as to what is the purpose of including the word 'film' in the definition of 'record' for the purposes of the Archives Act. Fear has been expressed that this will expand the role of the Australian Archives into the area of preserving film and having a film library, and that this would duplicate the work that is being done in this regard by the National Library.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to assure Senator Hamer and the Committee and all those who have been concerned about the matter that that is not the intention of the Government or, indeed, of the Australian Archives. The reason that the word 'film' appears in the definition of 'record' is that some departments have kept normal departmental files in the form of microfilm. Many departments have highly classified records in film form which are a necessary and integral part of their administrative activities. They must be treated under the conditions of security appropriate to their nature and therefore can only be provided for by the Archives. Only films produced by Commonwealth agencies are Commonwealth records. Films produced for commercial purposes by non-Commonwealth agencies are not Commonwealth records and do not come under the provisions of the legislation. In the broad, the matters of concern raised by Senator Hamer will not be the policy of the Archives. Indeed, such films will not be within the normal definition of 'film' that appears here. There might be an area where consultation and ministerial agreement between the Archives and other relevant authorities is necessary. That would be in relation to commercially-produced films with the production of which the Australian Film Commission is associated. Where the Commonwealth, through that Commission, makes grants for scripting or production of those films, there would be no question of Commonwealth ownership. In cases where the Commission invests in a film production along with commercial interests it might have a degree of ownership depending upon the legal basis on which the investment was made. But I understand that the Director-General of the Australian Archives and the National Library are agreed that they can and will negotiate on these matters as necessary. Therefore, there is no need to change the definition that appears. I want to make it very clear that it is certainly not the intention of the Government to change the present arrangements. Indeed, I doubt whether in most cases there would be, under the definition, any power in the Archives to do so.

I turn to the substance of the amendment moved by Senator Tate. The Bill as proposed proceeds on the basis that records of certain institutions will not be assigned to the Archives for custody purposes. The amendment proposes to extend the definition of a Commonwealth institution in a way which would cut across the policy which has been adopted by the Government. The intention has been that Executive Council records and records in relation to the Cabinet, the parliamentary departments and the courts generally would not be assigned to the custody of Archives. The reason for that is the special nature of such records. The records of the Executive Council and of the Governor-General are in a particularly sensitive and special category and arrangements have been in place for some time in relation to their custody. The United Kingdom Government and the Queen would have a very close interest in those records, and different arrangements are made in the United Kingdom from those made here. For instance, Palace records, I understand, have a closed access period of 60 years, not the 30 years under the arrangements here.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have made provision for that.

—Yes, I know, but the Government does not agree with that provision. We would prefer to retain the present arrangements rather than have the regulation-making power which, I understand Senator Tate to say, a later amendment will give. I have dealt with Executive Council records, which are the subject of the particular amendment, but there are other documents of a sensitive character such as Cabinet records. It is the Government's view that such records should be retained within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and not be deposited with Archives and that the records of the parliamentary departments should remain there.
—Do you think they will still be best sellers in 2012? That is what you are talking about.

—We all kid ourselves about the long term value of what is happening here. We believe that these arrangements are working perfectly well. At present there are arrangements between the Archives, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Government of the United Kingdom in relation to Executive Council minutes. Arrangements in relation to Cabinet records are made between Archives and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. I believe the success of these arrangements and of the attitude of the Government is shown in the fact that of all Cabinet records generated between the foundation of the Commonwealth and 1950 fewer than 200 have been exempted. The vast majority of such records are made available. I know that the amendment, if accepted, would provide a right of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and that, therefore, different rights would be created in relation to access, if it was refused. But it is not the Government's policy, as I have indicated from its past practice, to hold all but to hold only a very few records of this kind after the open access period of 30 years. Under the freedom of information legislation, when it is passed, anyone who is refused access will have the opportunity to take the matter up with the proposed Documents Review Tribunal and that Tribunal will be able to make its public recommendation to government. The pressure that we discussed in relation to the Freedom of Information Bill will be brought to bear on governments in that way. So, it is not true to say that the decision will be entirely one of government. Although it will be made by government, it will have that very strong influence of the views of the Documents Review Tribunal. The Government's attitude is that the actual custody of these records should be retained in the hands of those who for good reason have custody of them now, and that in the long run the amendment will not really affect access, after the open access period, to the vast majority of documents in this category.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) foresees a situation in which the records of the Governor-General and the Executive Council will not be available in the year 2012, does he foresee that the bulk of these records will not be available in the future?

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to raise a matter which I believe concerns Queensland residents who have paid more income tax than necessary because of an ambiguous instruction on income tax forms. Resident taxpayers are entitled to a concessional rebate of 32c for each dollar of allowable concessional expenditure greater than $1,590. Concessional expenditure includes such expenditure as medical and associated expenditures, funeral expenses, education expenses, rates and land taxes, life insurance premiums, superannuation, adoption expenses and calls paid to afforestation companies. This evening, however, I will deal with just education expenses.

SPEECH.PARA: The maximum rebatable amount which a taxpayer may claim for each dependent student is $250. On the 1981 income tax return-indeed, since 1977-taxpayers have been instructed to 'subtract Government assistance for fees and books'. Prior to 1977 taxpayers were instructed on the tax form to subtract the level of Federal Government assistance received. There is a real difference between deducting Federal Government assistance and deducting government assistance. In Queensland -similar situations may prevail in other States-the State Government grants a textbook allowance to secondary school students. The allowance varies from $20 a year to $60 a year depending upon the year of study. Since 1977 many taxpayers have been deducting the amount they have received by way of textbook allowance from the education expenses of their children. When the instruction on the income tax return is 'subtract Government assistance for fees and books', this would seem to be a reasonable course of action. One taxpayer who did this in Queensland was not convinced that he should have done so and asked to have his last three returns reviewed. He was subsequently granted a refund because he had included in his tax return the amount he had received by way of textbook allowance. At about the same time I wrote to the Treasurer (Mr Howard) about this general matter. In part, the Minister Assisting the Treasurer replied:
He-
That is, the Commissioner of Taxation-

advised that a specific provision of the income tax law authorises the reduction from a claim for education expenses of the amount of any allowance received or receivable under a scheme for the provision by the Commonwealth Government of secondary scholarships, technical scholarships or assistance in the education of isolated children. This is outlined on Page 2 of Schedule 'A' of the Income Tax Return Forms A or B.

The Commissioner went on to say that payments received from the State Government for book allowances are not treated as scholarship benefits or assistance and do not have to be subtracted from education expenses claimed as concessional rebatable expenditure.

So it is clear that taxpayers are not required to deduct State Government book allowances from expenditures they have incurred on behalf of their dependent children. Yet because of the way in which the tax form is worded some parents are obviously deducting these amounts. Some remedial action is necessary. Firstly, the Government must admit publicly that this wording on the income tax return form is ambiguous and invite taxpayers who may have been misled to ask for a review of their income tax assessments. Secondly, the Government must ensure that when the next income tax form is printed the word 'Commonwealth' or 'Federal' appears before the word 'Government' on the form. This will make it clear to those who are receiving State Government assistance for books that they should not subtract this amount from their education expenses.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall bring Senator Colston's remarks to the attention of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and ask him to give consideration to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution to this debate will be short. The subject matter is directed to you, Mr President. I was unhappy about the interference tonight by a gentleman from another place, who is a Minister, who had an animated conversation with a member of the Senate from the gallery behind me. On previous occasions about 20 years ago, not long before I came into this place, I happened to be in the other House when a similar sort of thing took place as members were filing into the chamber for a division. That matter finally finished up before the Privileges Committee because a member of the goverment of the day raised the matter with the Speaker. From memory, I think it was in 1960. In 1975 an honourable member from another place came into this House and spoke from the gallery in front of me to a member of the then Government. He also was required to submit an apology to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I realise that the Minister concerned, Mr N. A. Brown, and the Senator concerned, Senator Archer, are both comparatively new to the parliament. I realise that they probably do not know their Standing Orders. I was saddened by the fact that during the counting of the division when I could have raised it but did not because I did not want to interfere with the counting, you, Mr President, had looked around the chamber on several occasions and you failed to see this animated conversation going on. I was under the impression, in fact, that the visitor from another place sitting in the gallery was trying to persuade the senator to come and vote with the Opposition.

The dignity of this place has to be maintained and it is the responsibility not only of you, sir, but also of honourable senators on both sides of the chamber. If that is not maintained then any Tom, Dick and Harry can come into the galleries and conduct a conversation during a division and persuade people to change their vote if they are able to do so. I do not know whether that was the subject of the conversation tonight, but it was audible and it was witnessed by me and members of my party as we sat on your right hand during that division. I hope that this will not happen again. I am not asking for the matter to go to the Privileges Committee. I am seeking your assurance that it will never, ever be allowed to happen in this chamber while you occupy the very dignified and high office of President.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Keeffe, in response I can only say that I give you an assurance that I did not notice what you have stated to have taken place. I can also give you an unqualified assurance that I will uphold the dignity of this place and will take any necessary action if I see conduct between stranger and senator in this chamber.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
